**Madrid** ([/məˈdrɪd/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English") [](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/b/b7/LL-Q1860_%28eng%29-Vealhurl-Madrid.wav/LL-Q1860_%28eng%29-Vealhurl-Madrid.wav.mp3 "Play audio")^[ⓘ](/wiki/File:LL-Q1860_(eng)-Vealhurl-Madrid.wav "File:LL-Q1860 (eng)-Vealhurl-Madrid.wav")^ [*mə-DRID*](/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key "Help:Pronunciation respelling key");
Spanish: [\[maˈðɾið\]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Spanish "Help:IPA/Spanish") [](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/7/75/Pronunciation_of_Madrid_in_Spanish.ogg/Pronunciation_of_Madrid_in_Spanish.ogg.mp3 "Play audio")^[ⓘ](/wiki/File:Pronunciation_of_Madrid_in_Spanish.ogg "File:Pronunciation of Madrid in Spanish.ogg")^)^[\[n. 1\]](#cite_note-10)^ is the capital and [most populous municipality of Spain](/wiki/List_of_largest_cities_in_Spain "List of largest cities in Spain"). It has almost 3.4 million^[\[10\]](#cite_note-ine-11)^ inhabitants and a [metropolitan area](/wiki/Madrid_metropolitan_area "Madrid metropolitan area") population of approximately 7 million. It is the [second-largest city](/wiki/Largest_cities_of_the_European_Union_by_population_within_city_limits "Largest cities of the European Union by population within city limits") in the [European Union](/wiki/European_Union "European Union") (EU), and its [monocentric](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/monocentric "wikt:monocentric") [metropolitan area](/wiki/Madrid_metropolitan_area "Madrid metropolitan area") is the [second-largest](/wiki/List_of_metropolitan_areas_in_Europe_by_population "List of metropolitan areas in Europe by population") in the EU.^[\[2\]](#cite_note-demographia-2)^^[\[11\]](#cite_note-citypopulation.de-12)^^[\[12\]](#cite_note-un.org-13)^ The municipality covers 604.3 km^2^ (233.3 sq mi) geographical area.^[\[13\]](#cite_note-14)^ Madrid lies on the [River Manzanares](/wiki/Manzanares_(river) "Manzanares (river)") in the central part of the [Iberian Peninsula](/wiki/Iberian_Peninsula "Iberian Peninsula") at about 650 meters above mean sea level. The capital city of both Spain and the surrounding [autonomous community of Madrid](/wiki/Community_of_Madrid "Community of Madrid") (since 1983),^[\[14\]](#cite_note-Moreno-Fernández-15)^^: 44^ it is also the political, economic, and cultural centre of the country.^[\[15\]](#cite_note-16)^ The [climate of Madrid](/wiki/Climate_of_Madrid "Climate of Madrid") features hot summers and cool winters. The primitive core of Madrid, a walled military outpost, dates back to the late 9th century, under the [Emirate of Córdoba](/wiki/Emirate_of_C%C3%B3rdoba "Emirate of Córdoba"). Conquered by Christians in 1083 or 1085, it consolidated in the Late Middle Ages as a sizeable town of the [Crown of Castile](/wiki/Crown_of_Castile "Crown of Castile"). The development of Madrid as administrative centre fostered after 1561, as it became the permanent seat of the court of the [Hispanic Monarchy](/wiki/Hispanic_Monarchy_(political_entity) "Hispanic Monarchy (political entity)").{#cite_ref-16}

The Madrid urban agglomeration has the [fourth-largest GDP](/wiki/List_of_cities_by_GDP "List of cities by GDP") in the [European Union](/wiki/European_Union "European Union") and its influence in [politics](/wiki/Politics "Politics"), [education](/wiki/Education "Education"), [entertainment](/wiki/Entertainment "Entertainment"), [environment](/wiki/Built_environment "Built environment"), [media](/wiki/Mass_media "Mass media"), [fashion](/wiki/Fashion "Fashion"), [science](/wiki/Science "Science"), [culture](/wiki/Culture "Culture"), and the [arts](/wiki/Arts "Arts") all contribute to its status as one of the world's major [global cities](/wiki/Global_city "Global city").^[\[16\]](#cite_note-GaWC-17)^^[\[17\]](#cite_note-mori-m-foundation.or.jp-18)^ Madrid is considered the major financial centre^[\[18\]](#cite_note-GFCI-19)^ and the leading economic hub of the Iberian Peninsula and of [Southern Europe](/wiki/Southern_Europe "Southern Europe").^[\[19\]](#cite_note-mastercard.com-20)^^[\[17\]](#cite_note-mori-m-foundation.or.jp-18)^ The metropolitan area hosts major Spanish companies such as [Telefónica](/wiki/Telef%C3%B3nica "Telefónica"), [Iberia](/wiki/Iberia_(airline) "Iberia (airline)"), [BBVA](/wiki/BBVA "BBVA") and [FCC](/wiki/Fomento_de_Construcciones_y_Contratas "Fomento de Construcciones y Contratas").^[\[14\]](#cite_note-Moreno-Fernández-15)^^: 45^ It concentrates the bulk of banking operations in the country and it is the Spanish-speaking city generating the largest number of webpages.^[\[14\]](#cite_note-Moreno-Fernández-15)^^: 45^{#cite_ref-Moreno-Fernández_15-2}

Madrid houses the headquarters of the [UN](/wiki/United_Nations "United Nations")'s [World Tourism Organization](/wiki/World_Tourism_Organization "World Tourism Organization") (UNWTO), the [Ibero-American General Secretariat](/wiki/Ibero-American_General_Secretariat "Ibero-American General Secretariat") (SEGIB), the [Organization of Ibero-American States](/wiki/Organization_of_Ibero-American_States "Organization of Ibero-American States") (OEI), and the [Public Interest Oversight Board](/wiki/Public_Interest_Oversight_Board "Public Interest Oversight Board") (PIOB). It also hosts major international regulators and promoters of the Spanish language: the Standing Committee of the Association of Spanish Language Academies, headquarters of the [Royal Spanish Academy](/wiki/Royal_Spanish_Academy "Royal Spanish Academy") (RAE), the [Instituto Cervantes](/wiki/Instituto_Cervantes "Instituto Cervantes") and the Foundation of Urgent Spanish ([Fundéu](/wiki/Fund%C3%A9u "Fundéu")RAE). Madrid organises fairs such as FITUR,^[\[20\]](#cite_note-FITUR-21)^ ARCO,^[\[21\]](#cite_note-ARCO-22)^ [SIMO TCI](/wiki/SIMO_TCI "SIMO TCI")^[\[22\]](#cite_note-23)^ and the [Madrid Fashion Week](/wiki/Madrid_Fashion_Week "Madrid Fashion Week").^[\[23\]](#cite_note-24)^ Madrid is home to two world-famous [football](/wiki/Association_football "Association football") clubs, [Real Madrid](/wiki/Real_Madrid "Real Madrid") and [Atlético Madrid](/wiki/Atl%C3%A9tico_Madrid "Atlético Madrid").{#cite_ref-24}

While Madrid possesses modern infrastructure, it has preserved the look and feel of many of its historic neighbourhoods and streets. Its landmarks include the [Plaza Mayor](/wiki/Plaza_Mayor,_Madrid "Plaza Mayor, Madrid"), the [Royal Palace of Madrid](/wiki/Royal_Palace_of_Madrid "Royal Palace of Madrid"); the [Royal Theatre](/wiki/Teatro_Real "Teatro Real") with its restored 1850 Opera House; the [Buen Retiro Park](/wiki/Buen_Retiro_Park "Buen Retiro Park"), founded in 1631; the 19th-century [National Library](/wiki/Biblioteca_Nacional_de_Espa%C3%B1a "Biblioteca Nacional de España") building (founded in 1712) containing some of Spain's historical archives; many national museums,^[\[24\]](#cite_note-25)^ and the [Golden Triangle of Art](/wiki/Golden_Triangle_of_Art "Golden Triangle of Art"), located along the [Paseo del Prado](/wiki/Paseo_del_Prado "Paseo del Prado") and comprising three art museums: [Prado Museum](/wiki/Museo_del_Prado "Museo del Prado"), the [Reina Sofía Museum](/wiki/Museo_Nacional_Centro_de_Arte_Reina_Sof%C3%ADa "Museo Nacional Centro de Arte Reina Sofía"), a museum of [modern art](/wiki/Modern_art "Modern art"), and the [Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum](/wiki/Thyssen-Bornemisza_Museum "Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum"), which complements the holdings of the other two museums.^[\[25\]](#cite_note-Overview_of_Madrid-26)^ The mayor is [José Luis Martínez-Almeida](/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Luis_Mart%C3%ADnez-Almeida "José Luis Martínez-Almeida") from the [People's Party](/wiki/People%27s_Party_(Spain) "People's Party (Spain)").^[\[26\]](#cite_note-27)^{#cite_ref-27}  

Etymology {#Etymology}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: Etymology")\]

The origin of the name is unknown. There are various theories regarding the origin of the toponym "Madrid" (all of them with problems when it comes to fully explaining the phonetic evolution of the toponym), namely:^[\[27\]](#cite_note-Orozco-28)^{#cite_ref-Orozco_28-0}

* A [Celtic](/wiki/Continental_Celtic_languages "Continental Celtic languages") origin (Madrid \< \**Magetoritum* ;^[\[27\]](#cite_note-Orozco-28)^^: 701^ with the root "-ritu" meaning "[ford](/wiki/Ford_(crossing) "Ford (crossing)")").{#cite_ref-Orozco_28-1}
* From the [Arabic](/wiki/Arabic_language "Arabic language") *maǧrà* / majrā (meaning "water stream")^[\[27\]](#cite_note-Orozco-28)^^: 701^ or [Arabic](/wiki/Arabic_language "Arabic language"): ‏[مجريػ](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D9%85%D8%AC%D8%B1%D9%8A%D8%BB#Arabic "wikt:مجريػ")‎, [romanized](/wiki/Romanization_of_Arabic "Romanization of Arabic"): *mayrit*, [lit.](/wiki/Literal_translation "Literal translation") '"spring", "fountain"'.^[\[28\]](#cite_note-Khayat-29)^{#cite_ref-Khayat_29-0}
* A [Mozarabic](/wiki/Andalusi_Romance "Andalusi Romance") variant of the Latin *[matrix](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/matrix#Latin "wikt:matrix")* , *matricis* (also meaning "water stream").^[\[27\]](#cite_note-Orozco-28)^^: 701^{#cite_ref-Orozco_28-3}

Nicknames for Madrid include the plural *Los Madriles*^[\[29\]](#cite_note-CVC-30)^ and *La Villa y Corte* ( 'the town and [court](/wiki/Royal_court "Royal court")').{#cite_ref-CVC_30-0}  

History {#History}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section: History")\]  
Main article: [History of Madrid](/wiki/History_of_Madrid "History of Madrid")  
For a chronological guide, see [Timeline of Madrid](/wiki/Timeline_of_Madrid "Timeline of Madrid").

The site of modern-day Madrid has been occupied since prehistoric times,^[\[30\]](#cite_note-autogenerated4-31)^^[\[31\]](#cite_note-32)^^[\[32\]](#cite_note-33)^ and there are archaeological remains of the [Celtic](/wiki/Celts "Celts") [Carpetani](/wiki/Carpetani "Carpetani") settlement, [Roman villas](/wiki/Roman_villa "Roman villa"),^[\[33\]](#cite_note-34)^ a [Visigoth](/wiki/Visigoth "Visigoth") basilica near the church of Santa María de la Almudena^[\[34\]](#cite_note-35)^ and three Visigoth necropolises near Casa de Campo, Tetuán and Vicálvaro.^[\[35\]](#cite_note-36)^{#cite_ref-36}  

### Middle Ages {#Middle_Ages}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: Middle Ages")\]

The first historical document about the existence of an established settlement in Madrid dates from the [Muslim](/wiki/Muslim "Muslim") age. In the second half of the 9th century,^[\[36\]](#cite_note-37)^ [Umayyad](/wiki/Emirate_of_C%C3%B3rdoba "Emirate of Córdoba") Emir [Muhammad I](/wiki/Muhammad_I_of_C%C3%B3rdoba "Muhammad I of Córdoba") built a fortress on a headland near the river [Manzanares](/wiki/Manzanares_(river) "Manzanares (river)")^[\[37\]](#cite_note-38)^ as one of the many fortresses he ordered to be built on the border between [Al-Andalus](/wiki/Al-Andalus "Al-Andalus") and the kingdoms of [León](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Le%C3%B3n "Kingdom of León") and [Castile](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Castile "Kingdom of Castile"), with the objective of protecting [Toledo](/wiki/Toledo,_Spain "Toledo, Spain") from Christian attacks from the North and also as a starting point for Muslim offensives. After the disintegration of the [Caliphate of Córdoba](/wiki/Caliphate_of_C%C3%B3rdoba "Caliphate of Córdoba") in the early 11th century, Madrid was integrated in the [Taifa of Toledo](/wiki/Taifa_of_Toledo "Taifa of Toledo").{#cite_ref-38}

In the context of the wider campaign for the conquest of the taifa of Toledo initiated in 1079, Madrid was seized in 1083 by [Alfonso VI of León and Castile](/wiki/Alfonso_VI_of_Le%C3%B3n_and_Castile "Alfonso VI of León and Castile"), who sought to use the town as an offensive outpost against the city of Toledo,^[\[38\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBahamonde_MagroOtero_Carvajal19899-39)^ in turn conquered in 1085. Following the conquest, Christians occupied the center of the city, while Muslims and Jews were displaced to the suburbs. Madrid, located near [Alcalá](/wiki/Alcal%C3%A1_de_Henares "Alcalá de Henares") (under Muslim control until 1118), remained a borderland for a while, suffering a number of *[razzias](/wiki/Razzia_(military) "Razzia (military)")* during the [Almoravid](/wiki/Almoravid "Almoravid") period, and its walls were destroyed in 1110.^[\[38\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBahamonde_MagroOtero_Carvajal19899-39)^ The city was confirmed as *villa de [realengo](/w/index.php?title=Realengo_(legal_status)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Realengo (legal status) (page does not exist)") \[[es](https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/realengo "es:realengo")\]* (linked to the Crown) in 1123, during the reign of [Alfonso VII](/wiki/Alfonso_VII_of_Le%C3%B3n_and_Castile "Alfonso VII of León and Castile").^[\[39\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTECestero_ManceraMolina_MartosParedes_García201518-40)^ The 1123 Charter of Otorgamiento established the first explicit limits between Madrid and Segovia, namely the Puerto de El Berrueco and the Puerto de Lozoya.^[\[40\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTECerrillo_Torquemada2009245-41)^ Beginning in 1188, Madrid had the right to be a city with representation in the courts of Castile.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^ In 1202, [Alfonso VIII](/wiki/Alfonso_VIII_of_Castile "Alfonso VIII of Castile") gave Madrid its first charter to regulate the municipal council,^[\[41\]](#cite_note-42)^ which was expanded in 1222 by [Ferdinand III](/wiki/Ferdinand_III_of_Castile "Ferdinand III of Castile"). The government system of the town was changed to a *[regimiento](/wiki/Regimiento "Regimiento")* of 12 *[regidores](/wiki/Regidor "Regidor")* by [Alfonso XI](/wiki/Alfonso_XI_of_Castile "Alfonso XI of Castile") on 6 January 1346.^[\[42\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESuárez_Fernández2001137-43)^{#cite_ref-FOOTNOTESuárez_Fernández2001137_43-0}

Starting in the mid-13th century and up to the late 14th century, the *concejo* of Madrid vied for the control of the Real de Manzanares territory against the *concejo* of [Segovia](/wiki/Segovia "Segovia"), a powerful town north of the [Sierra de Guadarrama](/wiki/Sierra_de_Guadarrama "Sierra de Guadarrama") mountain range, characterised by its repopulating prowess and its husbandry-based economy, contrasted with the agricultural and less repopulated town of Madrid.^[\[43\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBahamonde_MagroOtero_Carvajal198911–12-44)^ After the decline of [Sepúlveda](/wiki/Sep%C3%BAlveda,_Segovia "Sepúlveda, Segovia"), another *concejo* north of the mountain range, Segovia had become a major actor south of the Guadarrama mountains, expanding across the [Lozoya](/wiki/Lozoya_(river) "Lozoya (river)") and [Manzanares](/wiki/Manzanares_River "Manzanares River") rivers to the north of Madrid and along the [Guadarrama river](/wiki/Guadarrama_(river) "Guadarrama (river)") course to its west.^[\[43\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBahamonde_MagroOtero_Carvajal198911–12-44)^{#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBahamonde_MagroOtero_Carvajal198911–12_44-1}

In 1309, the Courts of Castile convened at Madrid for the first time under [Ferdinand IV](/wiki/Ferdinand_IV_of_Castile "Ferdinand IV of Castile"), and later in 1329, 1339, 1391, 1393, 1419 and twice in 1435.  

### Modern Age {#Modern_Age}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: Modern Age")\]

During the [revolt of the Comuneros](/wiki/Revolt_of_the_Comuneros "Revolt of the Comuneros"), led by [Juan Lopez de Padilla](/wiki/Juan_Lopez_de_Padilla "Juan Lopez de Padilla"), Madrid joined the revolt against [Charles, Holy Roman Emperor](/wiki/Charles_V,_Holy_Roman_Emperor "Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor"), but after defeat at the [Battle of Villalar](/wiki/Battle_of_Villalar "Battle of Villalar"), Madrid was besieged and occupied by the imperial troops. The city was however granted the titles of *Coronada* (Crowned) and *Imperial*.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Dibujo_madrid_1562.JPG/800px-Dibujo_madrid_1562.JPG)](/wiki/File:Dibujo_madrid_1562.JPG) View of Madrid from the west, facing the Puerta de la Vega. Drawing by [Anton van den Wyngaerde](/wiki/Anton_van_den_Wyngaerde "Anton van den Wyngaerde"), 1562. [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Ba%C3%B1os_en_el_Manzanares_en_el_paraje_de_Molino_Quemado._Museo_de_Historia_de_Madrid_%28detalle%29.JPG/220px-Ba%C3%B1os_en_el_Manzanares_en_el_paraje_de_Molino_Quemado._Museo_de_Historia_de_Madrid_%28detalle%29.JPG)](/wiki/File:Ba%C3%B1os_en_el_Manzanares_en_el_paraje_de_Molino_Quemado._Museo_de_Historia_de_Madrid_(detalle).JPG) *Baths in the Manzanares in the place of Molino Quemado* (detail), by [Félix Castello](/wiki/F%C3%A9lix_Castello "Félix Castello") ( 1634--1637)

The number of urban inhabitants grew from 4,060 in the year 1530 to 37,500 in the year 1594. The poor population of the court was composed of ex-soldiers, foreigners, rogues and Ruanes, dissatisfied with the lack of food and high prices. In June 1561 [Phillip II](/wiki/Philip_II_of_Spain "Philip II of Spain") set his court in Madrid, installing it in the old [*alcázar*](/wiki/Royal_Alcazar_of_Madrid "Royal Alcazar of Madrid").^[\[44\]](#cite_note-45)^ Thanks to this, the city of Madrid became the political centre of the monarchy, being the capital of Spain except for a short period between 1601 and 1606, in which the Court was relocated to [Valladolid](/wiki/Valladolid "Valladolid") (and the Madrid population temporarily plummeted accordingly). Being the capital was decisive for the evolution of the city and influenced its fate and during the rest of the reign of Philip II, the population boomed, going up from about 18,000 in 1561 to 80,000 in 1598.^[\[45\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEParsons200313-46)^{#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEParsons200313_46-0}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Madrid_-_Calle_de_Alcal%C3%A1_in_18th-century_by_Antonio_Joli.jpg/220px-Madrid_-_Calle_de_Alcal%C3%A1_in_18th-century_by_Antonio_Joli.jpg)](/wiki/File:Madrid_-_Calle_de_Alcal%C3%A1_in_18th-century_by_Antonio_Joli.jpg) View of Calle de Alcalá in 1750 by [Antonio Joli](/wiki/Antonio_Joli "Antonio Joli")

During the early 17th century, although Madrid recovered from the loss of the capital status, with the return of diplomats, lords and affluent people, as well as an entourage of noted writers and artists together with them, extreme poverty was however rampant.^[\[46\]](#cite_note-47)^ The century also was a time of heyday for theatre, represented in the so-called [*corrales de comedias*](/wiki/Corral_de_comedias "Corral de comedias").^[\[47\]](#cite_note-48)^{#cite_ref-48}

The city changed hands several times during the [War of the Spanish Succession](/wiki/War_of_the_Spanish_succession "War of the Spanish succession"): from the Bourbon control it passed to the allied "Austracist" army with Portuguese and English presence that [entered the city in late June 1706](/w/index.php?title=First_entry_of_Archduke_Charles&action=edit&redlink=1 "First entry of Archduke Charles (page does not exist)") \[[es](https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Primera_entrada_en_Madrid_del_archiduque_Carlos "es:Primera entrada en Madrid del archiduque Carlos")\],^[\[48\]](#cite_note-49)^ only to be retaken by the Bourbon army on 4 August 1706.^[\[49\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMartínez_Pereira2008180-50)^ The Habsburg army led by the [Archduke Charles](/wiki/Charles_VI,_Holy_Roman_Emperor "Charles VI, Holy Roman Emperor") [entered the city for a second time](/w/index.php?title=Second_entry_of_Archduke_Charles_in_Madrid&action=edit&redlink=1 "Second entry of Archduke Charles in Madrid (page does not exist)") \[[es](https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Segunda_entrada_en_Madrid_del_archiduque_Carlos "es:Segunda entrada en Madrid del archiduque Carlos")\] in September 1710,^[\[50\]](#cite_note-51)^ leaving the city less than three months after. [Philip V](/wiki/Philip_V_of_Spain "Philip V of Spain") entered the capital on 3 December 1710.^[\[51\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEQuirós_Rosado2016308-52)^{#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEQuirós_Rosado2016308_52-0}

Seeking to take advantage of the Madrid's location at the geographic centre of Spain, the 18th century saw a sustained effort to create a radial system of communications and transports for the country through public investments.^[\[52\]](#cite_note-53)^{#cite_ref-53}

Philip V built the Royal Palace, the [Royal Tapestry Factory](/wiki/Royal_Tapestry_Factory "Royal Tapestry Factory") and the main Royal Academies.^[\[53\]](#cite_note-54)^ The reign of [Charles III](/wiki/Charles_III_of_Spain "Charles III of Spain"), who came to be known as "the best mayor of Madrid", saw an effort to turn the city into a true capital, with the construction of sewers, street lighting, cemeteries outside the city and a number of monuments and cultural institutions. The reforms enacted by his Sicilian minister were however opposed in 1766 by the populace in the so-called [Esquilache Riots](/wiki/Esquilache_Riots "Esquilache Riots"), a revolt demanding to repeal a clothing decree banning the use of traditional hats and [long cloaks](/wiki/Spaniard_cloak "Spaniard cloak") aiming to curb crime in the city.^[\[54\]](#cite_note-55)^{#cite_ref-55}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/El_dos_de_mayo_de_1808_en_Madrid.jpg/220px-El_dos_de_mayo_de_1808_en_Madrid.jpg)](/wiki/File:El_dos_de_mayo_de_1808_en_Madrid.jpg) *[The Second of May 1808](/wiki/The_Second_of_May_1808 "The Second of May 1808")* by [Francisco de Goya](/wiki/Francisco_de_Goya "Francisco de Goya")  
Main article: [Dos de Mayo Uprising](/wiki/Dos_de_Mayo_Uprising "Dos de Mayo Uprising")

In the context of the [Peninsular War](/wiki/Peninsular_War "Peninsular War"), the situation in French-occupied Madrid after March 1808 was becoming more and more tense. On 2 May, a crowd began to gather near the [Royal Palace](/wiki/Royal_Palace_of_Madrid "Royal Palace of Madrid") protesting against the French attempt to evict the remaining members of the Bourbon royal family to [Bayonne](/wiki/Bayonne "Bayonne"), prompting up an uprising against the French Imperial troops that lasted hours and spread throughout the city, including a famous last stand at the Monteleón barracks. Subsequent repression was brutal, with many insurgent Spaniards being [summarily executed](/wiki/Summary_execution "Summary execution").^[\[55\]](#cite_note-56)^ The uprising led to a declaration of war calling all the Spaniards to fight against the French invaders.{#cite_ref-56}  

### Capital of the Liberal State {#Capital_of_the_Liberal_State}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section: Capital of the Liberal State")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Plano_del_Ensanche_de_Madrid-1861.jpg/220px-Plano_del_Ensanche_de_Madrid-1861.jpg)](/wiki/File:Plano_del_Ensanche_de_Madrid-1861.jpg) 1861 map of the *Ensanche de Madrid*

The city was invaded on 24 May 1823 by a French army---the so-called [Hundred Thousand Sons of Saint Louis](/wiki/Hundred_Thousand_Sons_of_Saint_Louis "Hundred Thousand Sons of Saint Louis")---called to intervene to restore the [absolutism](/wiki/Absolute_monarchy "Absolute monarchy") of Ferdinand that the latter had been deprived from during the [1820--1823 *trienio liberal*](/wiki/Trienio_liberal "Trienio liberal").^[\[56\]](#cite_note-57)^ Unlike other European capitals, during the first half of the 19th century the only noticeable bourgeois elements in Madrid (that experienced a delay in its industrial development up to that point) were merchants.^[\[57\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGarcía_Ruiz2011192-58)^ The University of Alcalá de Henares was relocated to Madrid in 1836, becoming the [Central University](/wiki/Complutense_University_of_Madrid "Complutense University of Madrid").^[\[58\]](#cite_note-59)^{#cite_ref-59}

The economy of the city further modernized during the second half of the 19th century, consolidating its status as a service and financial centre. New industries were mostly focused in book publishing, construction and low-tech sectors.^[\[59\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGarcía_Ruiz2011193-60)^ The introduction of [railway transport](/wiki/Railway_transport "Railway transport") greatly helped Madrid's economic prowess, and led to changes in consumption patterns (such as the substitution of salted fish for fresh fish from the Spanish coasts) as well as further strengthening the city's role as a [logistics node](/wiki/Logistics "Logistics") in the country's distribution network.^[\[60\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGarcía_Ruiz2011194-61)^ Electric lighting in the streets was introduced in the 1890s.^[\[60\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGarcía_Ruiz2011194-61)^{#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGarcía_Ruiz2011194_61-1}

During the first third of the 20th century the population nearly doubled, reaching more than 850,000 inhabitants. New suburbs such as Las Ventas, [Tetuán](/wiki/Tetu%C3%A1n_(Madrid) "Tetuán (Madrid)") and El Carmen became the homes of the influx of workers, while [Ensanche](/wiki/Ensanche "Ensanche") became a middle-class neighbourhood of Madrid.^[\[61\]](#cite_note-62)^{#cite_ref-62}  

### Second Republic and Civil War {#Second_Republic_and_Civil_War}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit&section=6 "Edit section: Second Republic and Civil War")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Children_during_the_Madrid_bombing.jpg/170px-Children_during_the_Madrid_bombing.jpg)](/wiki/File:Children_during_the_Madrid_bombing.jpg) Children taking refuge during the Francoist bombings (1936--1937) over Madrid during the [Spanish Civil War](/wiki/Spanish_Civil_War "Spanish Civil War")

The [Spanish Constitution of 1931](/wiki/Spanish_Constitution_of_1931 "Spanish Constitution of 1931") was the first to legislate the location of the country's capital, setting it explicitly in Madrid. During the 1930s, Madrid enjoyed "great vitality"; it was demographically young, becoming urbanized and the centre of new political movements.^[\[62\]](#cite_note-63)^ During this time, major construction projects were undertaken, including the northern extension of the [Paseo de la Castellana](/wiki/Paseo_de_la_Castellana "Paseo de la Castellana"), one of Madrid's major thoroughfares.^[\[63\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMonteroCervera_Gil200916-64)^ The tertiary sector, including banking, insurance and telephone services, grew greatly.^[\[64\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMonteroCervera_Gil200920-65)^ Illiteracy rates were down to below 20%, and the city's cultural life grew notably during the so-called *Silver Age* of Spanish Culture; the sales of newspapers also increased.^[\[65\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMonteroCervera_Gil200921-66)^ Conversely, the proclamation of the Republic created a severe housing shortage. Slums and squalor grew due to high population growth and the influx of the poor to the city. Construction of affordable housing failed to keep pace and increased political instability discouraged economic investment in housing in the years immediately prior to the Civil War.^[\[66\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMonteroCervera_Gil200917;_18-67)^ Anti-clericalism and Catholicism lived side by side in Madrid; the [burning of convents](/wiki/Burning_of_convents_in_Spain_(1931) "Burning of convents in Spain (1931)") initiated after riots in the city in May 1931 worsened the political environment.^[\[67\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMonteroCervera_Gil200925;_26-68)^ However, the [1934 insurrection](/wiki/Revolution_of_1934 "Revolution of 1934") largely failed in the city.^[\[68\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMonteroCervera_Gil200926-69)^{#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMonteroCervera_Gil200926_69-0}

Madrid was one of the most heavily affected cities in the [Spanish Civil War](/wiki/Spanish_Civil_War "Spanish Civil War") (1936--1939). It was a stronghold of the [Republican faction](/wiki/Second_Spanish_Republic "Second Spanish Republic") from July 1936 and became an international symbol of [anti-fascist](/wiki/Anti-fascism "Anti-fascism") struggle during the conflict.^[\[69\]](#cite_note-70)^ The city suffered aerial bombing, and in November 1936, its western suburbs were the scene of an all-out battle.^[\[70\]](#cite_note-History_of_Madrid_2-71)^ The city fell to the Francoists in March 1939.{#cite_ref-History_of_Madrid_2_71-0}  
See also: [Siege of Madrid](/wiki/Siege_of_Madrid "Siege of Madrid") and [Republican repression in Madrid (1936--1939)](/wiki/Republican_repression_in_Madrid_(1936%E2%80%931939) "Republican repression in Madrid (1936–1939)")  

### Francoist dictatorship {#Francoist_dictatorship}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section: Francoist dictatorship")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Madrid%2C_Tetu%C3%A1n_1978_01.jpg/170px-Madrid%2C_Tetu%C3%A1n_1978_01.jpg)](/wiki/File:Madrid,_Tetu%C3%A1n_1978_01.jpg) The [calle de Bravo Murillo](/wiki/Calle_de_Bravo_Murillo "Calle de Bravo Murillo") in 1978

A staple of post-war Madrid (*Madrid de la posguerra* ) was the widespread use of [ration coupons](/wiki/Rationing "Rationing").^[\[71\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGarcía_BallesterosRevilla_González200616-72)^ Meat and fish consumption was scarce, resulting in high mortality due to malnutrition.^[\[72\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGarcía_BallesterosRevilla_González200617–18-73)^ Due to Madrid's history as a left-wing stronghold, the right-wing victors considered moving the capital elsewhere (most notably to [Seville](/wiki/Seville "Seville")), but such plans were never implemented. The [Franco regime](/wiki/Franco_regime "Franco regime") instead emphasized the city's history as the capital of formerly imperial Spain.^[\[73\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFaraldoRodríguez-López2019107–124-74)^{#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFaraldoRodríguez-López2019107–124_74-0}

The intense demographic growth experienced by the city via mass immigration from the rural areas of the country led to the construction of abundant housing in the peripheral areas of the city to absorb the new population (reinforcing the processes of social polarization of the city),^[\[74\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELópez_Simón2018175-75)^ initially comprising substandard housing (with as many as 50,000 [shacks](/wiki/Shack "Shack") scattered around the city by 1956).^[\[75\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELópez_Simón2018175;_178-76)^ A transitional planning intended to temporarily replace the shanty towns were the *poblados de absorción* , introduced since the mid-1950s in locations such as [Canillas](/wiki/Canillas_(Madrid) "Canillas (Madrid)"), [San Fermín](/wiki/San_Ferm%C3%ADn_(Madrid) "San Fermín (Madrid)"), Caño Roto, [Villaverde](/wiki/Villaverde_(Madrid) "Villaverde (Madrid)"), [Pan Bendito](/w/index.php?title=Pan_Bendito&action=edit&redlink=1 "Pan Bendito (page does not exist)") \[[es](https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pan_Bendito "es:Pan Bendito")\], [Zofío](/wiki/El_Zof%C3%ADo "El Zofío") and [Fuencarral](/wiki/Fuencarral "Fuencarral"), aiming to work as a sort of "high-end" shacks (with the destinataries participating in the construction of their own housing) but under the aegis of a wider coordinated urban planning.^[\[76\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTELópez_Simón2018179–180-77)^{#cite_ref-FOOTNOTELópez_Simón2018179–180_77-0}

Madrid grew through the annexation of neighboring municipalities, achieving the present extent of 607 km^2^ (234.36 sq mi). The south of Madrid became heavily industrialized, and there was significant [immigration](/wiki/Human_migration "Human migration") from rural areas of Spain. Madrid's newly built north-western districts became the home of a newly enriched middle class that appeared as result of the [1960s Spanish economic boom](/wiki/Spanish_miracle "Spanish miracle"), while the south-eastern periphery became a large working-class area, which formed the base for active cultural and political movements.^[\[70\]](#cite_note-History_of_Madrid_2-71)^{#cite_ref-History_of_Madrid_2_71-1}  

### Recent history {#Recent_history}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: Recent history")\]

After the fall of the Francoist regime, the new [1978 constitution](/wiki/Constitution_of_Spain "Constitution of Spain") confirmed Madrid as the capital of Spain. The [1979 municipal election](/wiki/1979_Madrid_City_Council_election "1979 Madrid City Council election") brought Madrid's first democratically elected mayor since the Second Republic to power.

Madrid was the scene of some of the most important events of the time, such as the mass demonstrations of support for democracy after the failed coup, [23-F](/wiki/23-F "23-F"), on 23 February 1981. The first democratic mayors belonged to the centre-left [PSOE](/wiki/PSOE "PSOE") ([Enrique Tierno Galván](/wiki/Enrique_Tierno_Galv%C3%A1n "Enrique Tierno Galván"), [Juan Barranco Gallardo](/wiki/Juan_Barranco_Gallardo "Juan Barranco Gallardo")). Since the late 1970s and through the 1980s Madrid became the center of the cultural movement known as *[la Movida](/wiki/Movida_madrile%C3%B1a "Movida madrileña")* . Conversely, just like in the rest of the country, a [heroin crisis](/wiki/Opioid_epidemic "Opioid epidemic") took a toll in the poor neighborhoods of Madrid in the 1980s.^[\[77\]](#cite_note-78)^{#cite_ref-78}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Puertadelsol2011.jpg/220px-Puertadelsol2011.jpg)](/wiki/File:Puertadelsol2011.jpg) [2011 Anti-austerity protests](/wiki/Anti-austerity_movement_in_Spain "Anti-austerity movement in Spain") in the [Puerta del Sol](/wiki/Puerta_del_Sol "Puerta del Sol")

Benefiting from increasing prosperity in the 1980s and 1990s, the capital city of Spain consolidated its position as an important economic, cultural, industrial, educational, and technological centre on the European continent.^[\[70\]](#cite_note-History_of_Madrid_2-71)^ During the mandate as Mayor of [José María Álvarez del Manzano](/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Mar%C3%ADa_%C3%81lvarez_del_Manzano "José María Álvarez del Manzano") construction of traffic tunnels below the city proliferated.^[\[78\]](#cite_note-79)^ The following administrations, also conservative, led by [Alberto Ruiz-Gallardón](/wiki/Alberto_Ruiz-Gallard%C3%B3n "Alberto Ruiz-Gallardón") and [Ana Botella](/wiki/Ana_Botella "Ana Botella") launched three unsuccessful bids for the 2012, 2016 and 2020 Summer Olympics.^[\[79\]](#cite_note-80)^ By 2005, Madrid was the leading European destination for migrants from [developing countries](/wiki/Developing_countries "Developing countries"), as well as the largest employer of non-European workforce in Spain.^[\[80\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMasterson-Algar201630-81)^ Madrid was a centre of the [anti-austerity protests](/wiki/Anti-austerity_movement_in_Spain "Anti-austerity movement in Spain") that erupted in Spain in 2011.^[\[81\]](#cite_note-82)^ As consequence of the spillover of the [2008 financial and mortgage crisis](/wiki/2008_financial_crisis "2008 financial crisis"), Madrid has been affected by the increasing number of second-hand homes held by banks and [house evictions](/wiki/Eviction "Eviction").^[\[82\]](#cite_note-83)^ The mandate of left-wing Mayor [Manuela Carmena](/wiki/Manuela_Carmena "Manuela Carmena") (2015--2019) delivered the renaturalization of the course of the [Manzanares](/wiki/Manzanares_River "Manzanares River") across the city.{#cite_ref-83}

Since the late 2010s, the challenges the city faces include the increasingly unaffordable rental prices (often in parallel with the [gentrification](/wiki/Gentrification "Gentrification") and the spike of tourist apartments in the city centre) and the profusion of [betting shops](/wiki/Betting_shop "Betting shop") in working-class areas, leading to an "epidemic" of gambling among young people.^[\[83\]](#cite_note-84)^^[\[84\]](#cite_note-elpais-85)^{#cite_ref-elpais_85-0}  

Geography {#Geography}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section: Geography")\]  

### Location {#Location}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section: Location")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Madrid%2C_Spain_ESA24382842.jpeg/220px-Madrid%2C_Spain_ESA24382842.jpeg)](/wiki/File:Madrid,_Spain_ESA24382842.jpeg) Madrid as seen by the [Sentinel-2](/wiki/Sentinel-2 "Sentinel-2") satellite in July 2022

Madrid lies in the centre of the Iberian peninsula on the southern [Meseta Central](/wiki/Meseta_Central "Meseta Central"), 60 km south of the [Guadarrama mountain range](/wiki/Guadarrama_mountain_range "Guadarrama mountain range") and straddling the [Jarama](/wiki/Jarama "Jarama") and [Manzanares](/wiki/Manzanares_(river) "Manzanares (river)") river sub-drainage basins, in the wider [Tagus River](/wiki/Tagus_River "Tagus River") catchment area. With an average altitude of 650 m (2,130 ft), Madrid is the second highest capital of [Europe](/wiki/Europe "Europe") (after [Andorra la Vella](/wiki/Andorra_la_Vella "Andorra la Vella")).^[\[85\]](#cite_note-86)^ The difference in altitude within the city proper ranges from the 700 m (2,297 ft) around [Plaza de Castilla](/wiki/Plaza_de_Castilla "Plaza de Castilla") in the north of city to the 570 m (1,870 ft) around *La China* wastewater treatment plant on the Manzanares' riverbanks, near the latter's confluence with the Fuente Castellana [thalweg](/wiki/Thalweg "Thalweg") in the south of the city.^[\[86\]](#cite_note-87)^ The [Monte de El Pardo](/wiki/Monte_de_El_Pardo "Monte de El Pardo") (a protected forested area covering over a quarter of the municipality) reaches its top altitude (843 m (2,766 ft)) on its perimeter, in the slopes surrounding [El Pardo reservoir](/w/index.php?title=El_Pardo_reservoir&action=edit&redlink=1 "El Pardo reservoir (page does not exist)") \[[es](https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Embalse_de_El_Pardo "es:Embalse de El Pardo")\] located at the north-western end of the municipality, in the [Fuencarral-El Pardo](/wiki/Fuencarral-El_Pardo "Fuencarral-El Pardo") district.^[\[87\]](#cite_note-88)^{#cite_ref-88}

The oldest urban core is located on the hills next to the left bank of the Manzanares River.^[\[88\]](#cite_note-plangen-89)^ The city grew to the east, reaching the [Fuente Castellana Creek](/w/index.php?title=Fuente_Castellana_Creek&action=edit&redlink=1 "Fuente Castellana Creek (page does not exist)") \[[es](https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arroyo_de_la_Fuente_Castellana "es:Arroyo de la Fuente Castellana")\] (now the [Paseo de la Castellana](/wiki/Paseo_de_la_Castellana "Paseo de la Castellana")), and further east reaching the [Abroñigal Creek](/w/index.php?title=Abro%C3%B1igal_Creek&action=edit&redlink=1 "Abroñigal Creek (page does not exist)") \[[es](https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arroyo_Abro%C3%B1igal "es:Arroyo Abroñigal")\] (now the [M-30](/wiki/Autopista_de_Circunvalaci%C3%B3n_M-30 "Autopista de Circunvalación M-30")).^[\[88\]](#cite_note-plangen-89)^ The city also grew through the annexation of neighbouring urban settlements,^[\[88\]](#cite_note-plangen-89)^ including those to the South West on the right bank of the Manzanares.{#cite_ref-plangen_89-2}  

### Parks and forests {#Parks_and_forests}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit&section=11 "Edit section: Parks and forests")\]  
Main article: [List of Madrid parks](/wiki/List_of_Madrid_parks "List of Madrid parks")  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Principales_parques_de_Madrid.svg/220px-Principales_parques_de_Madrid.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Principales_parques_de_Madrid.svg)  
Main parks in the municipality  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/El_Retiro_abrir%C3%A1_sus_puertas_a_las_14.00_horas_01.jpg/220px-El_Retiro_abrir%C3%A1_sus_puertas_a_las_14.00_horas_01.jpg)](/wiki/File:El_Retiro_abrir%C3%A1_sus_puertas_a_las_14.00_horas_01.jpg)  
[Retiro Park](/wiki/Retiro_Park "Retiro Park")  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Cuenca_del_r%C3%ADo_Manzanares_Monte_del_Pardo_26.JPG/220px-Cuenca_del_r%C3%ADo_Manzanares_Monte_del_Pardo_26.JPG)](/wiki/File:Cuenca_del_r%C3%ADo_Manzanares_Monte_del_Pardo_26.JPG)  
The [Manzanares](/wiki/Manzanares_(river) "Manzanares (river)") flowing through the [Monte de El Pardo](/wiki/Monte_de_El_Pardo "Monte de El Pardo")

Madrid has the second highest number of aligned trees in the world, with 248,000 units, only exceeded by Tokyo. Madrid's citizens have access to a green area within a 15-minute walk. Since 1997, green areas have increased by 16%. At present, 8.2% of Madrid's grounds are green areas, meaning that there are 16 m^2^ (172 sq ft) of green area per inhabitant, far exceeding the 10 m^2^ (108 sq ft) per inhabitant recommended by the World Health Organization.

A great bulk of the most important parks in Madrid are related to areas originally belonging to the royal assets (including El Pardo, Soto de Viñuelas, Casa de Campo, El Buen Retiro, la Florida and the [Príncipe Pío hill](/wiki/Pr%C3%ADncipe_P%C3%ADo_(hill) "Príncipe Pío (hill)"), and the Queen's Casino).^[\[89\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGaliana_Martín199446,_50-90)^ The other main source for the "green" areas are the *[bienes de propios](/w/index.php?title=Bienes_de_propios&action=edit&redlink=1 "Bienes de propios (page does not exist)") \[[es](https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/bienes_de_propios "es:bienes de propios")\]* owned by the municipality (including the Dehesa de la Villa, the Dehesa de Arganzuela or Viveros).^[\[90\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGaliana_Martín199450-91)^{#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGaliana_Martín199450_91-0}

[El Retiro](/wiki/Buen_Retiro_Park "Buen Retiro Park") is the most visited location of the city.^[\[91\]](#cite_note-92)^ Having an area bigger than 1.4 km^2^ (0.5 sq mi) (350 acres), it is the largest park within the [Almendra Central](/wiki/Almendra_Central "Almendra Central"), the inner part of the city enclosed by the M-30. Created during the reign of [Philip IV](/wiki/Philip_IV_of_Spain "Philip IV of Spain") (17th century), it was handed over to the municipality in 1868, after the Glorious Revolution.^[\[92\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGaliana_Martín199448-93)^^[\[93\]](#cite_note-94)^ It lies next to the [Royal Botanical Garden of Madrid](/wiki/Real_Jard%C3%ADn_Bot%C3%A1nico_de_Madrid "Real Jardín Botánico de Madrid").{#cite_ref-94}

Located northwest of the city centre, the [Parque del Oeste](/wiki/Parque_del_Oeste "Parque del Oeste") ("Park of the West") comprises part of the area of the former royal possession of the "Real Florida", and it features a slope as the height decreases down to the Manzanares.^[\[94\]](#cite_note-95)^ Its southern extension includes the [Temple of Debod](/wiki/Temple_of_Debod "Temple of Debod"), a transported ancient Egyptian temple.^[\[95\]](#cite_note-96)^{#cite_ref-96}

Other urban parks are the [Parque de El Capricho](/wiki/Parque_de_El_Capricho "Parque de El Capricho"), the [Parque Juan Carlos I](/wiki/Parque_Juan_Carlos_I "Parque Juan Carlos I") (both in northeast Madrid), [Madrid Río](/wiki/Madrid_R%C3%ADo "Madrid Río"), the [Enrique Tierno Galván Park](/w/index.php?title=Enrique_Tierno_Galv%C3%A1n_Park&action=edit&redlink=1 "Enrique Tierno Galván Park (page does not exist)") \[[es](https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parque_de_Enrique_Tierno_Galv%C3%A1n "es:Parque de Enrique Tierno Galván")\], the [San Isidro Park](/w/index.php?title=San_Isidro_Park&action=edit&redlink=1 "San Isidro Park (page does not exist)") \[[es](https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/parque_de_San_Isidro "es:parque de San Isidro")\] as well as gardens such as the [Campo del Moro](/wiki/Campo_del_Moro "Campo del Moro") (opened to the public in 1978)^[\[90\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGaliana_Martín199450-91)^ and the [Sabatini Gardens](/wiki/Sabatini_Gardens "Sabatini Gardens") (opened to the public in 1931)^[\[90\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGaliana_Martín199450-91)^ adjacent to the Royal Palace.{#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGaliana_Martín199450_91-2}

Further west, across the Manzanares, lies the [Casa de Campo](/wiki/Casa_de_Campo "Casa de Campo"), a large forested area with more than 1700 hectares (6.6 sq mi) where the [Madrid Zoo](/wiki/Zoo_Aquarium_de_Madrid "Zoo Aquarium de Madrid"), and the [Parque de Atracciones de Madrid](/wiki/Parque_de_Atracciones_de_Madrid "Parque de Atracciones de Madrid") amusement park are located. It was ceded to the municipality following the proclamation of the Second Spanish Republic in 1931.^[\[96\]](#cite_note-97)^{#cite_ref-97}

The [Monte de El Pardo](/wiki/Monte_de_El_Pardo "Monte de El Pardo") is the largest forested area in the municipality. A [holm oak](/wiki/Quercus_rotundifolia "Quercus rotundifolia") forest covering a surface over 16,000 hectares, it is considered the best preserved [mediterranean forest](/wiki/Mediterranean_forest "Mediterranean forest") in the Community of Madrid and one of the best preserved in Europe.^[\[97\]](#cite_note-foresta-98)^ Already mentioned in the [Alfonso XI](/wiki/Alfonso_XI_of_Castile "Alfonso XI of Castile")'s *[Libro de la montería](/w/index.php?title=Libro_de_la_monter%C3%ADa&action=edit&redlink=1 "Libro de la montería (page does not exist)") \[[es](https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Libro_de_la_monter%C3%ADa "es:Libro de la montería")\]* from the mid-14th century, its condition as hunting location linked to the Spanish monarchy help to preserve the environmental value.^[\[97\]](#cite_note-foresta-98)^ During the reign of Ferdinand VII the regime of hunting prohibition for the Monte de El Pardo became one of full property and the expropriation of all possessions within its bounds was enforced, with dire consequences for the madrilenians at the time.^[\[98\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGaliana_Martín199446-99)^ It is designated as [Special Protection Area](/wiki/Special_Protection_Area "Special Protection Area") for bird-life and it is also part of the Regional Park of the High Basin of the Manzanares.{#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGaliana_Martín199446_99-0}

Other large forested areas include the [Soto de Viñuelas](/wiki/Soto_de_Vi%C3%B1uelas "Soto de Viñuelas"), the [Dehesa de Valdelatas](/w/index.php?title=Dehesa_de_Valdelatas&action=edit&redlink=1 "Dehesa de Valdelatas (page does not exist)") \[[es](https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dehesa_de_Valdelatas "es:Dehesa de Valdelatas")\] and the [Dehesa de la Villa](/w/index.php?title=Dehesa_de_la_Villa&action=edit&redlink=1 "Dehesa de la Villa (page does not exist)") \[[es](https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dehesa_de_la_Villa "es:Dehesa de la Villa")\]. As of 2015, the most recent big park in the municipality is the Valdebebas Park. Covering a total area of 4.7 km^2^ (1.8 sq mi), it is sub-divided in a 3.4 km^2^ (1.3 sq mi) forest park (the [Parque forestal de Valdebebas-Felipe VI](/w/index.php?title=Parque_forestal_de_Valdebebas-Felipe_VI&action=edit&redlink=1 "Parque forestal de Valdebebas-Felipe VI (page does not exist)") \[[es](https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parque_forestal_de_Valdebebas-Felipe_VI "es:Parque forestal de Valdebebas-Felipe VI")\]), a 0.8 km^2^ (0.31 sq mi) periurban park as well as municipal garden centres and compost plants.^[\[99\]](#cite_note-100)^{#cite_ref-100}  

### Climate {#Climate}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit&section=12 "Edit section: Climate")\]  
Main article: [Climate of Madrid](/wiki/Climate_of_Madrid "Climate of Madrid")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/%28Castillejos%29_Vista_de_Madrid_desde_Plaza_de_Castilla_03_%28cropped%29.jpg/220px-%28Castillejos%29_Vista_de_Madrid_desde_Plaza_de_Castilla_03_%28cropped%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:(Castillejos)_Vista_de_Madrid_desde_Plaza_de_Castilla_03_(cropped).jpg) Madrid during a [rainstorm](/wiki/Rainstorm "Rainstorm")

Madrid has a [cold semi-arid climate](/wiki/Cold_semi-arid_climate "Cold semi-arid climate") ([Köppen](/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification "Köppen climate classification") *BSk* ), transitioning to a [Mediterranean climate](/wiki/Mediterranean_climate "Mediterranean climate") (Csa) in the western half.^[\[100\]](#cite_note-101)^ The city has continental influences.{#cite_ref-101}

Winters are cool due to its altitude, which is approximately 667 m (2,188 ft) [above sea level](/wiki/Above_mean_sea_level "Above mean sea level") and distance from the moderating effect of the sea. While mostly sunny, rain, sporadic snowfalls and frequent frosts can occur between December and February with cooler temperatures particularly during the night and mornings as cold winds blow into the city from surrounding mountains. Summers are hot and sunny, in the warmest month, July, average temperatures during the day range from 32 to 34 °C (90 to 93 °F) depending on location, with maxima commonly climbing over 35 °C (95 °F) and occasionally up to 40 °C during the frequent heat waves. Due to Madrid's altitude and dry climate, humidity is low and [diurnal ranges](/wiki/Diurnal_temperature_variation "Diurnal temperature variation") are often significant, particularly on sunny winter days when the temperature rises in the afternoon before rapidly plummeting after nightfall. Madrid is among the sunniest capital cities in Europe.

The highest recorded temperature was on 14 August 2021, with 40.7 °C (105.3 °F) and the lowest recorded temperature was on 16 January 1945 with −10.1 °C (13.8 °F) in Madrid.^[\[101\]](#cite_note-102)^ While at the airport, in the eastern side of the city, the highest recorded temperature was on 14 August 2021, at 42.7 °C (108.9 °F), and the lowest recorded temperature was on 16 January 1945 at −15.2 °C (4.6 °F).^[\[102\]](#cite_note-103)^ [From 7 to 9 January 2021](/wiki/Storm_Filomena "Storm Filomena"), Madrid received the most snow in its recorded history since 1904; Spain's meteorological agency [AEMET](/wiki/AEMET "AEMET") reported between 50 and 60 cm (20 and 24 in) of accumulated snow in its [weather stations](/wiki/Weather_station "Weather station") within the city.^[\[103\]](#cite_note-Pereda-104)^{#cite_ref-Pereda_104-0}

[Precipitation](/wiki/Precipitation_(meteorology) "Precipitation (meteorology)") is typically concentrated in the autumn, winter, and spring. It is particularly sparse during the summer, taking the form of about two showers and/or thunderstorms during the season. Madrid is the [european capital](/wiki/Europe "Europe") with the least amount of annual precipitation.^[\[104\]](#cite_note-105)^^[\[105\]](#cite_note-106)^{#cite_ref-106}

At the metropolitan scale, Madrid features both substantial daytime urban cool island and nighttime [urban heat island](/wiki/Urban_heat_island "Urban heat island") effects during the summer season in relation to its surroundings, which feature thinly vegetated dry land.^[\[106\]](#cite_note-107)^{#cite_ref-107}

### Water supply {#Water_supply}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit&section=13 "Edit section: Water supply")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Comienza_la_restauraci%C3%B3n_del_Viaje_de_Agua_de_Amaniel_para_permitir_visitas_did%C3%A1cticas_04.jpg/220px-Comienza_la_restauraci%C3%B3n_del_Viaje_de_Agua_de_Amaniel_para_permitir_visitas_did%C3%A1cticas_04.jpg)](/wiki/File:Comienza_la_restauraci%C3%B3n_del_Viaje_de_Agua_de_Amaniel_para_permitir_visitas_did%C3%A1cticas_04.jpg) Viaje de Amaniel

In the 17th century, the *viajes de agua* (a kind of water channel or *[qanat](/wiki/Qanat "Qanat")* ) were used to provide water to the city. Some of the most important ones were the [Viaje de Amaniel](/w/index.php?title=Viaje_de_Amaniel&action=edit&redlink=1 "Viaje de Amaniel (page does not exist)") \[[es](https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Viaje_de_Amaniel "es:Viaje de Amaniel")\] (1610--1621, sponsored by the Crown), the [Viaje de Fuente Castellana](/w/index.php?title=Viaje_de_Fuente_Castellana&action=edit&redlink=1 "Viaje de Fuente Castellana (page does not exist)") \[[es](https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Viaje_de_la_Castellana "es:Viaje de la Castellana")\] (1613--1620) and [Abroñigal Alto](/w/index.php?title=Abro%C3%B1igal_Alto&action=edit&redlink=1 "Abroñigal Alto (page does not exist)") \[[es](https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abro%C3%B1igal_Alto "es:Abroñigal Alto")\]/[Abroñigal Bajo](/w/index.php?title=Abro%C3%B1igal_Bajo&action=edit&redlink=1 "Abroñigal Bajo (page does not exist)") \[[es](https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bajo_Abro%C3%B1igal "es:Bajo Abroñigal")\] (1617--1630), sponsored by the City Council. They were the main infrastructure for the supply of water until the arrival of the [Canal de Isabel II](/wiki/Canal_de_Isabel_II "Canal de Isabel II") in the mid-19th century.^[\[111\]](#cite_note-112)^{#cite_ref-112}

Madrid derives almost 73.5 percent of its [water supply](/wiki/Water_supply "Water supply") from dams and reservoirs built on the [Lozoya River](/wiki/Lozoya_(river) "Lozoya (river)"), such as the [El Atazar Dam](/wiki/El_Atazar_Dam "El Atazar Dam").^[\[112\]](#cite_note-113)^ This water supply is managed by the Canal de Isabel II, a public entity created in 1851. It is responsible for the supply, depurating waste water and the conservation of all the natural water resources of the Madrid region.{#cite_ref-113}  

Demographics {#Demographics}
----------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit&section=14 "Edit section: Demographics")\]  
Main article: [Demographics of Madrid](/wiki/Demographics_of_Madrid "Demographics of Madrid")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Community_of_Madrid_population_pyramid_in_2022.svg/220px-Community_of_Madrid_population_pyramid_in_2022.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Community_of_Madrid_population_pyramid_in_2022.svg) [Community of Madrid](/wiki/Community_of_Madrid "Community of Madrid") population pyramid in 2022

The population of Madrid has overall increased since the city became the capital of Spain in the mid-sixteenth century, and has stabilised at approximately 3,000,000 since the 1970s.

From 1970 until the mid-1990s, the population dropped. This phenomenon, which also affected other European cities, was caused in part by the growth of satellite suburbs at the expense of the downtown region within the city proper.

The [demographic boom](/wiki/Population_growth "Population growth") accelerated in the late-1990s and early first decade of the 21st century due to [immigration](/wiki/Immigration "Immigration") in parallel with a surge in Spanish [economic growth](/wiki/Economic_growth "Economic growth").

The wider Madrid region is the EU region with the highest average life expectancy at birth. The average life expectancy was 82.2 years for males and 87.8 for females in 2016.^[\[113\]](#cite_note-114)^{#cite_ref-114}

As the capital city of Spain, the city has attracted many immigrants from around the world, with most of the immigrants coming from [Latin American](/wiki/Latin_America "Latin America") countries.^[\[114\]](#cite_note-115)^ In 2020, around 76% of the registered population was Spain-born,^[\[115\]](#cite_note-foreignborn-116)^ while, regarding the foreign-born population (24%),^[\[115\]](#cite_note-foreignborn-116)^ the bulk of it relates to [the Americas](/wiki/Americas "Americas") (around 16% of the total population), and a lesser fraction of the population is born in other [European](/wiki/Europe "Europe"), [Asian](/wiki/Asia "Asia") and [African](/wiki/Africa "Africa") countries.{#cite_ref-foreignborn_116-1}

As of 2019, the fastest-growing group of immigrants were [Venezuelans](/wiki/Venezuelans_in_Spain "Venezuelans in Spain"), who consisted of a population of 60,000 in Madrid alone. This made them the second-largest community of foreign origin at the time after [Ecuadorians](/wiki/Ecuadorians_in_Spain "Ecuadorians in Spain"), with a population of 88,000.^[\[116\]](#cite_note-117)^{#cite_ref-117}

Regarding religious beliefs, according to a 2019 [Centro de Investigaciones Sociológicas](/wiki/Centro_de_Investigaciones_Sociol%C3%B3gicas "Centro de Investigaciones Sociológicas") (CIS) survey with a sample size of 469 respondents, 20.7% of respondents in Madrid identify themselves as practising [Catholics](/wiki/Catholic "Catholic"), 45.8% as non-practising Catholics, 3.8% as believers of another religion, 11.1% as [agnostics](/wiki/Agnosticism "Agnosticism"), 3.6% as indifferent towards religion, and 12.8% as [atheists](/wiki/Atheism "Atheism"). The remaining 2.1% did not state their religious beliefs.^[\[117\]](#cite_note-118)^{#cite_ref-118}

The Madrid metropolitan area comprises Madrid and the surrounding municipalities. According to [Eurostat](/wiki/Eurostat "Eurostat"), the "metropolitan region" of Madrid has a population of slightly more than 6.271 million people^[\[118\]](#cite_note-Eurostat-119)^ covering an area of 4,609.7 km^2^ (1,780 sq mi). It is the largest in Spain and the [second largest in the European Union](/wiki/List_of_metropolitan_areas_in_Europe_by_population "List of metropolitan areas in Europe by population").^[\[2\]](#cite_note-demographia-2)^^[\[11\]](#cite_note-citypopulation.de-12)^^[\[12\]](#cite_note-un.org-13)^{#cite_ref-un.org_13-1}

### Local government and administration {#Local_government_and_administration}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit&section=16 "Edit section: Local government and administration")\]  
Main article: [City Council of Madrid](/wiki/City_Council_of_Madrid "City Council of Madrid")  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Palacio_de_Comunicaciones_-_47.jpg/220px-Palacio_de_Comunicaciones_-_47.jpg)](/wiki/File:Palacio_de_Comunicaciones_-_47.jpg)  
Façade of the city hall  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/El_Ayuntamiento_izar%C3%A1_un_estandarte_a_favor_de_la_accesibilidad_universal_como_s%C3%ADmbolo_de_la_reivindicaci%C3%B3n_de_este_derecho_01.jpg/220px-El_Ayuntamiento_izar%C3%A1_un_estandarte_a_favor_de_la_accesibilidad_universal_como_s%C3%ADmbolo_de_la_reivindicaci%C3%B3n_de_este_derecho_01.jpg)](/wiki/File:El_Ayuntamiento_izar%C3%A1_un_estandarte_a_favor_de_la_accesibilidad_universal_como_s%C3%ADmbolo_de_la_reivindicaci%C3%B3n_de_este_derecho_01.jpg)  
A plenary session of the city council

The City Council (*Ayuntamiento de Madrid* ) is the body responsible for the government and administration of the municipality. It is formed by the Plenary (*Pleno* ), the Mayor (*alcalde* ) and the Government Board (*Junta de Gobierno de la Ciudad de Madrid*).

The Plenary of the Ayuntamiento is the body of [political representation](/wiki/Representation_(politics) "Representation (politics)") of the citizens in the [municipal government](/wiki/Local_government "Local government"). Its 57 members are elected for a 4-year mandate. Some of its attributions are: fiscal matters, the election and deposition of the mayor, the approval and modification of decrees and regulations, the approval of budgets, the agreements related to the limits and alteration of the municipal term, the services management, the participation in supramunicipal organisations, etc.^[\[119\]](#cite_note-120)^{#cite_ref-120}

The mayor, the supreme representative of the city, presides over the [*Ayuntamiento*](/wiki/Ayuntamiento_(Spain) "Ayuntamiento (Spain)"). He is charged with giving impetus to the municipal policies, managing the action of the rest of bodies and directing the executive municipal administration.^[\[120\]](#cite_note-121)^ He is responsible to the *Pleno* . He is also entitled to preside over the meetings of the *Pleno* , although this responsibility can be delegated to another municipal councillor. [José Luis Martínez-Almeida](/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Luis_Mart%C3%ADnez-Almeida "José Luis Martínez-Almeida"), a member of the [People's Party](/wiki/People%27s_Party_(Spain) "People's Party (Spain)"), has served as mayor since 2019.{#cite_ref-121}

The Government Board consists of the mayor, deputy mayors and a number of delegates assuming the portfolios for the different government areas. All those positions are held by municipal councillors.^[\[121\]](#cite_note-122)^{#cite_ref-122}

Since 2007, the [Cybele Palace](/wiki/Cybele_Palace "Cybele Palace") (or Palace of Communications) serves as [City Hall](/wiki/City_Hall "City Hall").  

### Capital of Spain {#Capital_of_Spain}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit&section=17 "Edit section: Capital of Spain")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Moncloa_011_%28cropped%29.jpg/220px-Moncloa_011_%28cropped%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Moncloa_011_(cropped).jpg) [Moncloa Palace](/wiki/Moncloa_Palace "Moncloa Palace"), seat of the [President of the Government of Spain](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Spain "Prime Minister of Spain")

Madrid is the capital of Spain. The [King of Spain](/wiki/King_of_Spain "King of Spain"), the country's head of state, has his official residence in the [Zarzuela Palace](/wiki/Palace_of_Zarzuela "Palace of Zarzuela"). As the seat of the [Government of Spain](/wiki/Government_of_Spain "Government of Spain"), Madrid also houses the official residence of the [President of the Government](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Spain "Prime Minister of Spain") (Prime Minister) and regular meeting place of the [Council of Ministers](/wiki/Council_of_Ministers_(Spain) "Council of Ministers (Spain)"), the [Moncloa Palace](/wiki/Palace_of_Moncloa "Palace of Moncloa"), as well as the headquarters of the ministerial departments. Both the residences of the head of state and government are located at the northwest of the city. Additionally, the seats of the Lower and Upper Chambers of the Spanish Parliament, the Cortes Generales (respectively, the [Palacio de las Cortes](/wiki/Palacio_de_las_Cortes "Palacio de las Cortes") and the [Palacio del Senado](/wiki/Palacio_del_Senado "Palacio del Senado")), also lie in Madrid.  

### Regional capital {#Regional_capital}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit&section=18 "Edit section: Regional capital")\]

Madrid is the capital of the Community of Madrid. The region has its own legislature and enjoys a wide range of competencies in areas such as social spending, healthcare, and education. The seat of the regional parliament, the [Assembly of Madrid](/wiki/Assembly_of_Madrid "Assembly of Madrid"), is located at the district of [Puente de Vallecas](/wiki/Puente_de_Vallecas "Puente de Vallecas"). The [presidency of the regional government](/wiki/President_of_the_Community_of_Madrid "President of the Community of Madrid") is headquartered at the [Royal House of the Post Office](/wiki/Royal_House_of_the_Post_Office "Royal House of the Post Office") at the very centre of the city, the [Puerta del Sol](/wiki/Puerta_del_Sol "Puerta del Sol").  

### Law enforcement {#Law_enforcement}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit&section=19 "Edit section: Law enforcement")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Manuela_Carmena_y_Javier_Barbero_reciben_a_la_nueva_promoci%C3%B3n_de_Polic%C3%ADa_Municipal_04.jpg/220px-Manuela_Carmena_y_Javier_Barbero_reciben_a_la_nueva_promoci%C3%B3n_de_Polic%C3%ADa_Municipal_04.jpg)](/wiki/File:Manuela_Carmena_y_Javier_Barbero_reciben_a_la_nueva_promoci%C3%B3n_de_Polic%C3%ADa_Municipal_04.jpg) Municipal police agents from the 2018 promotion

The [Madrid Municipal Police](/wiki/Polic%C3%ADa_Municipal_de_Madrid "Policía Municipal de Madrid") (*Policía Municipal de Madrid* ) is the local law enforcement body, dependent on the *Ayuntamiento* . As of 2018, it had a workforce of 6,190 civil servants.^[\[122\]](#cite_note-123)^{#cite_ref-123}

The headquarters of both the [Directorate-General of the Police](/wiki/Directorate-General_of_the_Police "Directorate-General of the Police") and the [Directorate-General of the Civil Guard](/wiki/Directorate-General_of_the_Civil_Guard "Directorate-General of the Civil Guard") are located in Madrid. The headquarters of the Higher Office of Police of Madrid (*Jefatura Superior de Policía de Madrid* ), the peripheral branch of the [National Police Corps](/wiki/Cuerpo_Nacional_de_Polic%C3%ADa "Cuerpo Nacional de Policía") with jurisdiction over the region also lies in Madrid.

Economy {#Economy}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit&section=21 "Edit section: Economy")\]  
Main article: [Economy of Madrid](/wiki/Economy_of_Madrid "Economy of Madrid")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/Interior_del_Palacio_de_la_Bolsa%2C_Madrid%2C_Espa%C3%B1a%2C_2017_29.jpg/220px-Interior_del_Palacio_de_la_Bolsa%2C_Madrid%2C_Espa%C3%B1a%2C_2017_29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Interior_del_Palacio_de_la_Bolsa,_Madrid,_Espa%C3%B1a,_2017_29.jpg) The [Madrid Stock Exchange](/wiki/Bolsa_de_Madrid "Bolsa de Madrid")

After it became the capital of Spain in the 16th century, Madrid was more a centre of [consumption](/wiki/Consumption_(economics) "Consumption (economics)") than of production or trade. Economic activity was largely devoted to supplying the city's own rapidly growing population, including the royal household and national government, and to such trades as [banking](/wiki/Bank "Bank") and [publishing](/wiki/Publishing "Publishing").

A large [industrial sector](/wiki/Industrial_sector "Industrial sector") did not develop until the 20th century, but thereafter industry greatly expanded and diversified, making Madrid the second industrial city in Spain. However, the economy of the city is now becoming more and more dominated by the [service sector](/wiki/Tertiary_sector_of_the_economy "Tertiary sector of the economy"). A major European financial center, its stock market is the third largest stock market in Europe featuring both the [IBEX 35](/wiki/IBEX_35 "IBEX 35") index and the attached [Latibex](/w/index.php?title=Latibex&action=edit&redlink=1 "Latibex (page does not exist)") \[[es](https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latibex "es:Latibex")\] stock market (with the second most important index for [Latin American](/wiki/Latin_America "Latin America") companies).^[\[14\]](#cite_note-Moreno-Fernández-15)^^: 45^{#cite_ref-Moreno-Fernández_15-3}

Madrid is the 5th most important leading Centre of Commerce in Europe (after London, Paris, Frankfurt and Amsterdam) and ranks 11th in the world.^[\[19\]](#cite_note-mastercard.com-20)^ It is the leading Spanish-speaking city in terms of webpage creation.^[\[14\]](#cite_note-Moreno-Fernández-15)^^: 45^{#cite_ref-Moreno-Fernández_15-4}  

### Economic history {#Economic_history}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit&section=22 "Edit section: Economic history")\]

As the capital city of the [Spanish Empire](/wiki/Spanish_Empire "Spanish Empire") from 1561, Madrid's population grew rapidly. Administration, banking, and small-scale manufacturing centred on the royal court were among the main activities, but the city was more a locus of consumption than production or trade, geographically isolated as it was before the coming of the railways.

The [Bank of Spain](/wiki/Bank_of_Spain "Bank of Spain") is one of the oldest European central banks. Originally named as the Bank of San Carlos as it was founded in 1782, it was later renamed to Bank of San Fernando in 1829 and ultimately became the Bank of Spain in 1856.^[\[124\]](#cite_note-125)^ [Its headquarters](/wiki/Bank_of_Spain_Building "Bank of Spain Building") are located at the [calle de Alcalá](/wiki/Calle_de_Alcal%C3%A1 "Calle de Alcalá"). The [Madrid Stock Exchange](/wiki/Bolsa_de_Madrid "Bolsa de Madrid") was inaugurated on 20 October 1831.^[\[125\]](#cite_note-126)^ Its benchmark stock market index is the [IBEX 35](/wiki/IBEX_35 "IBEX 35").{#cite_ref-126}

Industry started to develop on a large scale only in the 20th century,^[\[126\]](#cite_note-Historia-127)^ but then grew rapidly, especially during the "[Spanish miracle](/wiki/Spanish_miracle "Spanish miracle")" period around the 1960s. The economy of the city was then centred on manufacturing industries such as those related to [motor vehicles](/wiki/Motor_vehicle "Motor vehicle"), aircraft, chemicals, electronic devices, pharmaceuticals, [processed food](/wiki/Food_processing "Food processing"), printed materials, and leather goods.^[\[127\]](#cite_note-Overview:_Economy-128)^ Since the restoration of democracy in the late 1970s, the city has continued to expand. Its economy is now among the most dynamic and diverse in the [European Union](/wiki/European_Union "European Union").^[\[128\]](#cite_note-129)^{#cite_ref-129}  

### Present-day economy {#Present-day_economy}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit&section=23 "Edit section: Present-day economy")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Distrito_Telef%C3%B3nica_%28Madrid%29_09.jpg/220px-Distrito_Telef%C3%B3nica_%28Madrid%29_09.jpg)](/wiki/File:Distrito_Telef%C3%B3nica_(Madrid)_09.jpg) [Telefónica](/wiki/Telef%C3%B3nica "Telefónica") headquarters

Madrid concentrates activities directly connected with power (central and regional government, headquarters of Spanish companies, regional HQ of [multinationals](/wiki/Multinational_corporation "Multinational corporation"), [financial institutions](/wiki/Finance "Finance")) and with knowledge and technological innovation (research centres and universities). It is one of Europe's largest financial centres, and the largest in Spain.^[\[129\]](#cite_note-Estructura-130)^ The city has 17 universities and over 30 research centres.^[\[129\]](#cite_note-Estructura-130)^^: 52^ It is the second metropolis in the EU by population, and the third by gross internal product.^[\[129\]](#cite_note-Estructura-130)^^: 69^ Leading employers include [Telefónica](/wiki/Telef%C3%B3nica "Telefónica"), [Iberia](/wiki/Iberia_(airline) "Iberia (airline)"), [Prosegur](/wiki/Prosegur "Prosegur"), [BBVA](/wiki/BBVA "BBVA"), Urbaser, [Dragados](/wiki/Dragados "Dragados"), and [FCC](/wiki/Fomento_de_Construcciones_y_Contratas "Fomento de Construcciones y Contratas").^[\[129\]](#cite_note-Estructura-130)^^: 569^{#cite_ref-Estructura_130-3}

The [Community of Madrid](/wiki/Community_of_Madrid "Community of Madrid"), the region comprising the city and the rest of municipalities of the province, had a [GDP](/wiki/GDP "GDP") of [€](/wiki/%E2%82%AC "€")220B in 2017, equating to a GDP per capita of €33,800.^[\[130\]](#cite_note-131)^ In 2011 the city itself had a GDP per capita 74% above the national average and 70% above that of the 27 [European Union](/wiki/European_Union "European Union") member states, although 11% behind the average of the top 10 cities of the EU.^[\[129\]](#cite_note-Estructura-130)^^: 237--239^ Although housing just over 50% of the [region](/wiki/Community_of_Madrid "Community of Madrid")'s population, the city generates 65.9% of its GDP.^[\[129\]](#cite_note-Estructura-130)^^: 51^ Following the [recession](/wiki/2008%E2%80%9314_Spanish_financial_crisis "2008–14 Spanish financial crisis") commencing 2007/8, recovery was under way by 2014, with forecast growth rates for the city of 1.4% in 2014, 2.7% in 2015 and 2.8% in 2016.^[\[131\]](#cite_note-Barometro-132)^^: 10^{#cite_ref-Barometro_132-0}

The economy of Madrid has become based increasingly on the [service sector](/wiki/Tertiary_sector_of_the_economy "Tertiary sector of the economy"). In 2011 services accounted for 85.9% of value added, while [industry](/wiki/Industrial_sector "Industrial sector") contributed 7.9% and [construction](/wiki/Construction "Construction") 6.1%.^[\[129\]](#cite_note-Estructura-130)^^: 51^ Nevertheless, Madrid continues to hold the position of Spain's second industrial centre after Barcelona, specialising particularly in high-technology production. Following the recession, services and industry were forecast to return to growth in 2014, and construction in 2015.^[\[131\]](#cite_note-Barometro-132)^^: 32^^\[*[needs update](/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items "Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers")*\]^{#cite_ref-Barometro_132-1}  

#### Standard of living {#Standard_of_living}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit&section=24 "Edit section: Standard of living")\]

Mean household income and spending are 12% above the Spanish average.^[\[129\]](#cite_note-Estructura-130)^^: 537, 553^ The proportion classified as "at risk of poverty" in 2010 was 15.6%, up from 13.0% in 2006 but less than the average for Spain of 21.8%. The proportion classified as affluent was 43.3%, much higher than Spain overall (28.6%).^[\[129\]](#cite_note-Estructura-130)^^: 540--3^{#cite_ref-Estructura_130-8}

Consumption by Madrid residents has been affected by job losses and by [austerity](/wiki/Austerity "Austerity") measures, including a rise in sales tax from 8% to 21% in 2012.^[\[132\]](#cite_note-133)^{#cite_ref-133}

Although residential property prices have fallen by 39% since 2007, the average price of dwelling space was €2,375.6 per sq. m. in early 2014,^[\[131\]](#cite_note-Barometro-132)^^: 70^ and is shown as second only to London in a list of 22 European cities.^[\[133\]](#cite_note-134)^{#cite_ref-134}  

#### Employment {#Employment}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit&section=25 "Edit section: Employment")\]

Participation in the labour force was 1,638,200 in 2011, or 79.0%. The employed workforce comprised 49% women in 2011 (Spain, 45%).^[\[129\]](#cite_note-Estructura-130)^^: 98^ 41% of economically active people are university graduates, against 24% for Spain as a whole.^[\[129\]](#cite_note-Estructura-130)^^: 103^{#cite_ref-Estructura_130-10}

In 2011, the unemployment rate was 15.8%, remaining lower than in Spain as a whole. Among those aged 16--24, the unemployment rate was 39.6%.^[\[129\]](#cite_note-Estructura-130)^^: 97, 100^ Unemployment reached a peak of 19.1% in 2013,^[\[131\]](#cite_note-Barometro-132)^^: 17^ but with the start of an economic recovery in 2014, employment started to increase.^[\[134\]](#cite_note-135)^ Employment continues to shift further towards the service sector, with 86% of all jobs in this sector by 2011, against 74% in all of Spain.^[\[129\]](#cite_note-Estructura-130)^^: 117^ In the second quarter of 2018 the unemployment rate was 10.06%.^[\[135\]](#cite_note-136)^{#cite_ref-136}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/Madrid_2012_16_%287250774262%29.jpg/220px-Madrid_2012_16_%287250774262%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Madrid_2012_16_(7250774262).jpg) Headquarters of the [Bank of Spain](/wiki/Bank_of_Spain "Bank of Spain")  

#### Services {#Services}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit&section=26 "Edit section: Services")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Se_cumplen_35_a%C3%B1os_de_la_apertura_de_Mercamadrid_02.jpg/220px-Se_cumplen_35_a%C3%B1os_de_la_apertura_de_Mercamadrid_02.jpg)](/wiki/File:Se_cumplen_35_a%C3%B1os_de_la_apertura_de_Mercamadrid_02.jpg) [Mercamadrid](/wiki/Mercamadrid "Mercamadrid") facilities in South-Eastern Madrid

The share of services in the city's economy is 86%. Services for business, transport \& communications, property, and financial together account for 52% of the total value added.^[\[129\]](#cite_note-Estructura-130)^^: 51^ The types of services that are now expanding are mainly those that facilitate movement of capital, information, goods and persons, and "advanced business services" such as [research and development](/wiki/Research_and_development "Research and development") (R\&D), [information technology](/wiki/Information_technology "Information technology"), and technical [accountancy](/wiki/Accountancy "Accountancy").^[\[129\]](#cite_note-Estructura-130)^^: 242--3^{#cite_ref-Estructura_130-14}

Madrid and the wider region's authorities have put a notable effort in the development of [logistics infrastructure](/wiki/Logistics_center "Logistics center"). Within the city proper, some of the standout centres include [Mercamadrid](/wiki/Mercamadrid "Mercamadrid"), the [Madrid-Abroñigal](/w/index.php?title=Madrid-Abro%C3%B1igal_Station&action=edit&redlink=1 "Madrid-Abroñigal Station (page does not exist)") \[[es](https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Estaci%C3%B3n_de_Madrid-Abro%C3%B1igal "es:Estación de Madrid-Abroñigal")\] logistics centre, the Villaverde's Logistics Centre and the Vicálvaro's Logistics Centre to name a few.^[\[136\]](#cite_note-137)^{#cite_ref-137}

[Banks](/wiki/Bank "Bank") based in Madrid carry out 72% of the banking activity in Spain.^[\[129\]](#cite_note-Estructura-130)^^: 474^ The Spanish [central bank](/wiki/Central_bank "Central bank"), [Bank of Spain](/wiki/Bank_of_Spain "Bank of Spain"), has existed in Madrid since 1782. Stocks \& shares, [bond](/wiki/Bond_(finance) "Bond (finance)") markets, [insurance](/wiki/Insurance "Insurance"), and [pension funds](/wiki/Pension_fund "Pension fund") are other important forms of financial institution in the city.{#cite_ref-Estructura_130-15}

Madrid is an important centre for [trade fairs](/wiki/Trade_fair "Trade fair"), many of them coordinated by [IFEMA](/wiki/IFEMA "IFEMA"), the Trade Fair Institution of Madrid.^[\[129\]](#cite_note-Estructura-130)^^: 351--2^ The [public sector](/wiki/Public_sector "Public sector") employs 18.1% of all employees.^[\[129\]](#cite_note-Estructura-130)^^: 630^ Madrid attracts about 8M [tourists](/wiki/Tourism "Tourism") annually from other parts of Spain and from all over the world, exceeding even [Barcelona](/wiki/Barcelona "Barcelona").^[\[129\]](#cite_note-Estructura-130)^^: 81^^[\[129\]](#cite_note-Estructura-130)^^: 362, 374^^[\[131\]](#cite_note-Barometro-132)^^: 44^ Spending by tourists in Madrid was estimated (2011) at €9,546.5M, or 7.7% of the city's GDP.^[\[129\]](#cite_note-Estructura-130)^^: 375^{#cite_ref-Estructura_130-20}

The construction of [transport](/wiki/Transport_in_Madrid "Transport in Madrid") infrastructure has been vital to maintain the economic position of Madrid. Travel to work and other local journeys use a high-capacity metropolitan road network and a well-used [public transport](/wiki/Public_transport "Public transport") system.^[\[129\]](#cite_note-Estructura-130)^^: 62--4^ In terms of longer-distance transport, Madrid is the central node of the system of *[autovías](/wiki/Autov%C3%ADa "Autovía")* and of the [high-speed rail](/wiki/High-speed_rail "High-speed rail") network ([AVE](/wiki/AVE "AVE")), which has brought major cities such as Seville and Barcelona within 2.5 hours travel time.^[\[129\]](#cite_note-Estructura-130)^^: 72--75^ Also important to the city's economy is [Madrid-Barajas Airport](/wiki/Madrid-Barajas_Airport "Madrid-Barajas Airport"), the fourth largest airport in Europe.^[\[129\]](#cite_note-Estructura-130)^^: 76--78^ Madrid's central location makes it a major [logistical](/wiki/Logistics "Logistics") base.^[\[129\]](#cite_note-Estructura-130)^^: 79--80^{#cite_ref-Estructura_130-24}  

#### Industry {#Industry}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit&section=27 "Edit section: Industry")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/F%C3%A1brica_PSA_de_Madrid%2C_pista_pruebas_y_aparcamiento.JPG/220px-F%C3%A1brica_PSA_de_Madrid%2C_pista_pruebas_y_aparcamiento.JPG)](/wiki/File:F%C3%A1brica_PSA_de_Madrid,_pista_pruebas_y_aparcamiento.JPG) [PSA Peugeot Citroën](/wiki/Groupe_PSA "Groupe PSA") plant in [Villaverde](/wiki/Villaverde_(Madrid) "Villaverde (Madrid)") district

As an industrial centre Madrid retains its advantages in infrastructure, as a transport hub, and as the location of headquarters of many companies. Industries based on advanced technology are acquiring much more importance here than in the rest of Spain.^[\[129\]](#cite_note-Estructura-130)^^: 271^ Industry contributed 7.5% to Madrid's value-added in 2010.^[\[129\]](#cite_note-Estructura-130)^^: 265^ However, industry has slowly declined within the city boundaries as more industry has moved outward to the periphery.
