Industrial Gross Value Added grew by 4.3% in the period 2003--2005, but decreased by 10% during 2008--2010.^[\[129\]](#cite_note-Estructura-130)^^: 271, 274^ The leading industries were: paper, printing \& publishing, 28.8%; energy \& mining, 19.7%; vehicles \& transport equipment, 12.9%; electrical and electronic, 10.3%; foodstuffs, 9.6%; clothing, footwear \& textiles, 8.3%; chemical, 7.9%; industrial machinery, 7.3%.^[\[129\]](#cite_note-Estructura-130)^^: 266^{#cite_ref-Estructura_130-28}

The [PSA Peugeot Citroën](/wiki/Groupe_PSA "Groupe PSA") plant is located in [Villaverde](/wiki/Villaverde_(Madrid) "Villaverde (Madrid)") district.  

#### Construction {#Construction}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit&section=28 "Edit section: Construction")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/Caleido_%28agosto_2018%29.JPG/220px-Caleido_%28agosto_2018%29.JPG)](/wiki/File:Caleido_(agosto_2018).JPG) Building works of [Caleido](/wiki/Caleido "Caleido") in August 2018

The construction sector, contributing 6.5% to the city's economy in 2010,^[\[129\]](#cite_note-Estructura-130)^^: 265^ was a growing sector before the recession, aided by a large transport and infrastructure program. More recently the construction sector has fallen away and earned 8% less in 2009 than it had been in 2000.^[\[129\]](#cite_note-Estructura-130)^^: 242--3^ The decrease was particularly marked in the residential sector, where prices dropped by 25%--27% from 2007 to 2012/13^[\[129\]](#cite_note-Estructura-130)^^: 202, 212^ and the number of sales fell by 57%.^[\[129\]](#cite_note-Estructura-130)^^: 216^{#cite_ref-Estructura_130-32}  

#### Tourism {#Tourism}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit&section=29 "Edit section: Tourism")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/MADRID_060126_MXALX_067.jpg/220px-MADRID_060126_MXALX_067.jpg)](/wiki/File:MADRID_060126_MXALX_067.jpg) Fitur fair in Ifema

Madrid is the seat of the [World Tourism Organization](/wiki/World_Tourism_Organization "World Tourism Organization") (UNWTO) and the [International Tourism Fair](/w/index.php?title=International_Tourism_Fair&action=edit&redlink=1 "International Tourism Fair (page does not exist)") \[[es](https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/FITUR "es:FITUR")\] (FITUR).

In 2018, the city received 10.21 million tourists (53.3% of them international tourists).^[\[137\]](#cite_note-MADdestino-138)^^p. 9^ The biggest share of international tourists come from the United States, followed by Italy, France, United Kingdom and Germany.^[\[137\]](#cite_note-MADdestino-138)^^p. 10^ As of 2018, the city has 793 hotels, 85,418 hotel places and 43,816 hotel rooms.^[\[137\]](#cite_note-MADdestino-138)^^p. 18^ It also had, as of 2018, an estimated 20,217 tourist apartments.^[\[137\]](#cite_note-MADdestino-138)^^p. 20^{#cite_ref-MADdestino_138-3}

The most visited museum was the *[Museo Nacional Centro de Arte Reina Sofía](/wiki/Museo_Nacional_Centro_de_Arte_Reina_Sof%C3%ADa "Museo Nacional Centro de Arte Reina Sofía")* , with 3.8 million visitors in the sum of its three seats in 2018. Conversely, the [Prado Museum](/wiki/Prado_Museum "Prado Museum") had 2.8 million visitors and the [Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum](/wiki/Thyssen-Bornemisza_Museum "Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum") 906,815 visitors.^[\[137\]](#cite_note-MADdestino-138)^^p. 32^{#cite_ref-MADdestino_138-4}

By the late 2010s, the gentrification and the spike of tourist apartments in the city centre led to an increase in rental prices, pushing residents out of the city centre.^[\[84\]](#cite_note-elpais-85)^ Most of the tourist apartments in Madrid (50--54%) are located in the Centro District.^[\[138\]](#cite_note-eldiario-139)^ In the [Sol](/wiki/Sol_(Madrid) "Sol (Madrid)") neighborhood (part of the latter district), 3 out of 10 homes are dedicated to tourist apartments,^[\[138\]](#cite_note-eldiario-139)^ and 2 out of 10 are listed in [AirBnB](/wiki/AirBnB "AirBnB").^[\[84\]](#cite_note-elpais-85)^ In April 2019 the plenary of the *ayuntamiento* passed a plan intending to regulate this practice, seeking to greatly limit the number of tourist apartments. The normative would enforce a requirement for independent access to those apartments on and off the street.^[\[139\]](#cite_note-140)^ However, after the change of government in June 2019, the new municipal administration planned to revert the regulation.^[\[140\]](#cite_note-141)^{#cite_ref-141}  

#### International rankings {#International_rankings}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit&section=30 "Edit section: International rankings")\]

A recent study placed Madrid 7th among 36 cities as an attractive base for business.^[\[141\]](#cite_note-142)^ It was placed third in terms of availability of office space, and fifth for ease of access to markets, availability of qualified staff, mobility within the city, and quality of life. Its less favourable characteristics were seen as pollution, languages spoken, and political environment. Another ranking of European cities placed Madrid 5th among 25 cities (behind [Berlin](/wiki/Berlin "Berlin"), [London](/wiki/London "London"), [Paris](/wiki/Paris "Paris") and [Frankfurt](/wiki/Frankfurt "Frankfurt")), being rated favourably on economic factors and the labour market as well as transport and communication.^[\[142\]](#cite_note-143)^{#cite_ref-143}  

### Media and entertainment {#Media_and_entertainment}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit&section=31 "Edit section: Media and entertainment")\]

The Madrid metropolitan area is an important film and television production hub, whose content is distributed throughout the [Spanish-speaking world](/wiki/Spanish-speaking_world "Spanish-speaking world") and abroad. It is often seen as the entry point into the European media market for [Latin American](/wiki/Latin_America "Latin America") media companies, and likewise the entry point into the Latin American markets for European companies.^[\[143\]](#cite_note-144)^ It is also the headquarters of media groups such as [Radiotelevisión Española](/wiki/RTVE "RTVE") (RTVE), [Atresmedia](/wiki/Atresmedia "Atresmedia"), [Mediaset España](/wiki/Mediaset_Espa%C3%B1a "Mediaset España"), and [Movistar+](/wiki/Movistar%2B "Movistar+"), which produce numerous films, television shows and series which are distributed globally on various platforms.^[\[144\]](#cite_note-145)^ Since 2018, it is also home to [Netflix](/wiki/Netflix "Netflix")'s Madrid Production Hub, [Mediapro Studio](/wiki/Mediapro "Mediapro"), and numerous others such as [Viacom International Studios](/wiki/Viacom_International_Media_Networks "Viacom International Media Networks").^[\[145\]](#cite_note-146)^^[\[146\]](#cite_note-147)^^[\[147\]](#cite_note-148)^^[\[148\]](#cite_note-149)^ As of 2019, the film and television industry employs 19,000 people locally (44% of people in Spain working in this industry).^[\[149\]](#cite_note-150)^{#cite_ref-150}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/El_Piruli_and_neighbourhood.jpg/220px-El_Piruli_and_neighbourhood.jpg)](/wiki/File:El_Piruli_and_neighbourhood.jpg) [TVE](/wiki/Televisi%C3%B3n_Espa%C3%B1ola "Televisión Española")'s central news services are located at the foot of [Torrespaña](/wiki/Torrespa%C3%B1a "Torrespaña").

The [Torrespaña](/wiki/Torrespa%C3%B1a "Torrespaña") [broadcasting tower](/wiki/Radio_masts_and_towers "Radio masts and towers"), located in Madrid's [Salamanca](/wiki/Salamanca_(Madrid) "Salamanca (Madrid)") district, is the central and main transmission node of the terrestrial broadcasting network in Spain. RTVE, the state-owned radio and television [public broadcaster](/wiki/Public_broadcasting "Public broadcasting") is [headquartered](/wiki/Prado_del_Rey_(studios) "Prado del Rey (studios)") in [Pozuelo de Alarcón](/wiki/Pozuelo_de_Alarc%C3%B3n "Pozuelo de Alarcón") along with all its channels and web services ([La 1](/wiki/La_1_(Spanish_TV_channel) "La 1 (Spanish TV channel)"), [La 2](/wiki/La_2_(Spanish_TV_channel) "La 2 (Spanish TV channel)"), [Clan](/wiki/Clan_(TV_channel) "Clan (TV channel)"), [Teledeporte](/wiki/Teledeporte "Teledeporte"), [24 Horas](/wiki/24_Horas_(Spanish_TV_channel) "24 Horas (Spanish TV channel)"), [TVE Internacional](/wiki/TVE_Internacional "TVE Internacional"), [Radio Nacional](/wiki/Radio_Nacional_(Spanish_radio_station) "Radio Nacional (Spanish radio station)"), [Radio Exterior](/wiki/Radio_Exterior "Radio Exterior"), and [Radio Clásica](/wiki/Radio_Cl%C3%A1sica "Radio Clásica")). Atresmedia group ([Antena 3](/wiki/Antena_3_(Spain) "Antena 3 (Spain)"), [La Sexta](/wiki/La_Sexta "La Sexta"), [Onda Cero](/wiki/Onda_Cero "Onda Cero")) is headquartered in [San Sebastián de los Reyes](/wiki/San_Sebasti%C3%A1n_de_los_Reyes "San Sebastián de los Reyes"). [Mediaset España](/wiki/Mediaset_Espa%C3%B1a "Mediaset España") ([Telecinco](/wiki/Telecinco "Telecinco"), [Cuatro](/wiki/Cuatro_(TV_channel) "Cuatro (TV channel)")) maintains its headquarters in Madrid's [Fuencarral-El Pardo](/wiki/Fuencarral-El_Pardo "Fuencarral-El Pardo") district. Together with RTVE, Atresmedia and Mediaset account for nearly the 80% of share of [generalist television](/wiki/Generalist_channel "Generalist channel").^[\[150\]](#cite_note-enguix-151)^ The Spanish media conglomerate [PRISA](/wiki/PRISA "PRISA") ([Cadena SER](/wiki/Cadena_SER "Cadena SER"), [Los 40 Principales](/wiki/Los_40_Principales "Los 40 Principales"), [M80 Radio](/wiki/M80_Radio "M80 Radio"), [Cadena Dial](/wiki/Cadena_Dial "Cadena Dial")) is headquartered in [Gran Vía](/wiki/Gran_V%C3%ADa,_Madrid "Gran Vía, Madrid") street in central Madrid.{#cite_ref-enguix_151-0}

Besides hosting the main television and radio producers and broadcasters, the metropolitan area hosts most of the major written mass media in Spain,^[\[150\]](#cite_note-enguix-151)^ including *[ABC](/wiki/ABC_(newspaper) "ABC (newspaper)")* , *[El País](/wiki/El_Pa%C3%ADs "El País")* , *[El Mundo](/wiki/El_Mundo_(Spain) "El Mundo (Spain)")* , *[La Razón](/wiki/La_Raz%C3%B3n_(Madrid) "La Razón (Madrid)")* , *[Marca](/wiki/Marca_(newspaper) "Marca (newspaper)")* , *[¡Hola!](/wiki/%C2%A1Hola! "¡Hola!")* , *[Diario AS](/wiki/Diario_AS "Diario AS")* , *[El Confidencial](/wiki/El_Confidencial "El Confidencial")* and *[Cinco Días](/wiki/Cinco_D%C3%ADas "Cinco Días")* . The Spanish international news agency [EFE](/wiki/EFE "EFE") maintains its headquarters in Madrid since its inception in 1939. The second news agency of Spain is the privately owned [Europa Press](/wiki/Europa_Press_(news_agency) "Europa Press (news agency)"), founded and headquartered in Madrid since 1953.{#cite_ref-enguix_151-1}  

Culture {#Culture}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit&section=32 "Edit section: Culture")\]  

### Architecture {#Architecture}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit&section=33 "Edit section: Architecture")\]  
Main article: [Architecture of Madrid](/wiki/Architecture_of_Madrid "Architecture of Madrid")

|----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg) | This section **needs additional citations for [verification](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")** . Please help [improve this article](/wiki/Special:EditPage/Madrid "Special:EditPage/Madrid") by [adding citations to reliable sources](/wiki/Help:Referencing_for_beginners "Help:Referencing for beginners") in this section. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed. *(January 2015)**([Learn how and when to remove this message](/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal "Help:Maintenance template removal"))* |

Little medieval architecture is preserved in Madrid, mostly in the [Almendra Central](/wiki/Almendra_Central "Almendra Central"), including the [San Nicolás](/wiki/Church_of_San_Nicol%C3%A1s_(Madrid) "Church of San Nicolás (Madrid)") and [San Pedro el Viejo](/wiki/San_Pedro_el_Real,_Madrid "San Pedro el Real, Madrid") church towers, the church of [San Jerónimo el Real](/wiki/San_Jer%C3%B3nimo_el_Real "San Jerónimo el Real"), and the [Bishop's Chapel](/wiki/Chapel_of_Obispo_de_Madrid "Chapel of Obispo de Madrid"). Nor has Madrid retained much Renaissance architecture, other than the [Bridge of Segovia](/wiki/Bridge_of_Segovia_(Madrid) "Bridge of Segovia (Madrid)") and the [Convent of Las Descalzas Reales](/wiki/Convent_of_Las_Descalzas_Reales "Convent of Las Descalzas Reales").
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/Plaza_Mayor_de_Madrid_-_01.jpg/220px-Plaza_Mayor_de_Madrid_-_01.jpg)](/wiki/File:Plaza_Mayor_de_Madrid_-_01.jpg) [Plaza Mayor](/wiki/Plaza_Mayor,_Madrid "Plaza Mayor, Madrid"), built in the 16th century

Philip II moved his court to Madrid in 1561 and transformed the town into a capital city. During the Early Habsburg period, the import of European influences took place, underpinned by the monicker of *Austrian style* . The Austrian style featured not only Austrian influences but also Italian and Dutch (as well as Spanish), reflecting on the international preeminence of the Habsburgs.^[\[151\]](#cite_note-152)^ During the second half of the 16th century, the use of pointy slate [spires](/wiki/Spire "Spire") in order to top structures such as church towers was imported to Spain from Central Europe.^[\[152\]](#cite_note-153)^ Slate spires and roofs consequently became a staple of the Madrilenian architecture at the time.^[\[153\]](#cite_note-lib-154)^{#cite_ref-lib_154-0}

Stand out architecture in the city dating back to the early 17th century includes several buildings and structures (most of them attributed to [Juan Gómez de Mora](/wiki/Juan_G%C3%B3mez_de_Mora "Juan Gómez de Mora")) such as the [Palace of the Duke of Uceda](/wiki/Palacio_de_los_Concejos "Palacio de los Concejos") (1610), the [Monastery of La Encarnación](/wiki/Royal_Monastery_of_La_Encarnaci%C3%B3n "Royal Monastery of La Encarnación") (1611--1616); the [Plaza Mayor](/wiki/Plaza_Mayor_de_Madrid "Plaza Mayor de Madrid") (1617--1619) or the *Cárcel de Corte* (1629--1641), currently known as the [Santa Cruz Palace](/wiki/Santa_Cruz_Palace,_Madrid "Santa Cruz Palace, Madrid").^[\[154\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBlasco_Esquivias2016280-155)^ The century also saw the construction of the former City Hall, the [Casa de la Villa](/w/index.php?title=Casa_de_la_Villa&action=edit&redlink=1 "Casa de la Villa (page does not exist)").^[\[155\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEscobar200760–63-156)^{#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEscobar200760–63_156-0}

The [Imperial College](/wiki/Colegio_Imperial_de_Madrid "Colegio Imperial de Madrid") church model dome was imitated in all of Spain. [Pedro de Ribera](/wiki/Pedro_de_Ribera "Pedro de Ribera") introduced [Churrigueresque](/wiki/Churrigueresque "Churrigueresque") architecture to Madrid; the [Cuartel del Conde-Duque](/wiki/Cuartel_del_Conde-Duque "Cuartel del Conde-Duque"), the [church of Montserrat](/wiki/Our_Lady_of_Montserrat_Church,_Madrid "Our Lady of Montserrat Church, Madrid"), and the [Bridge of Toledo](/wiki/Bridge_of_Toledo_(Madrid) "Bridge of Toledo (Madrid)") are among the best examples.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Palacio_Real_Jardines.jpg/220px-Palacio_Real_Jardines.jpg)](/wiki/File:Palacio_Real_Jardines.jpg) [Royal Palace of Madrid](/wiki/Royal_Palace_of_Madrid "Royal Palace of Madrid"), built in the 18th century

The reign of [the Bourbons](/wiki/Bourbon_Spain "Bourbon Spain") during the eighteenth century marked a new era in the city. [Philip V](/wiki/Philip_V_of_Spain "Philip V of Spain") tried to complete King Philip II's vision of urbanisation of Madrid. Philip V built a palace in line with French taste, as well as other buildings such as [St. Michael's Basilica](/wiki/St._Michael%27s_Basilica_(Madrid) "St. Michael's Basilica (Madrid)") and the [Church of Santa Bárbara](/wiki/Church_of_Santa_Barbara,_Madrid "Church of Santa Barbara, Madrid"). King [Charles III](/wiki/Charles_III_of_Spain "Charles III of Spain") beautified the city and endeavoured to convert Madrid into one of the great European capitals. He pushed forward the construction of the Prado Museum (originally intended as a Natural Science Museum), the [Puerta de Alcalá](/wiki/Puerta_de_Alcal%C3%A1 "Puerta de Alcalá"), the [Royal Observatory](/wiki/Royal_Observatory_of_Madrid "Royal Observatory of Madrid"), the [Basilica of San Francisco el Grande](/wiki/Basilica_of_San_Francisco_el_Grande "Basilica of San Francisco el Grande"), the Casa de Correos in [Puerta del Sol](/wiki/Puerta_del_Sol "Puerta del Sol"), the [Real Casa de la Aduana](/wiki/Real_Casa_de_la_Aduana "Real Casa de la Aduana"), and the General Hospital (which now houses the Reina Sofia Museum and Royal Conservatory of Music). The [Paseo del Prado](/wiki/Paseo_del_Prado "Paseo del Prado"), surrounded by gardens and decorated with neoclassical statues, is an example of urban planning. The [Duke of Berwick](/wiki/Duke_of_Berwick "Duke of Berwick") ordered the construction of the [Liria Palace](/wiki/Liria_Palace "Liria Palace").

During the early 19th century, the [Peninsular War](/wiki/Peninsular_War "Peninsular War"), the [loss of viceroyalties](/wiki/Spanish_American_wars_of_independence "Spanish American wars of independence") in the Americas, and continuing coups limited the city's architectural development ([Royal Theatre](/wiki/Teatro_Real "Teatro Real"), the [National Library of Spain](/wiki/Biblioteca_Nacional_de_Espa%C3%B1a "Biblioteca Nacional de España"), the Palace of the Senate, and the [Congress](/wiki/Congress_of_Deputies_(Spain)#Congress_of_Deputies_building "Congress of Deputies (Spain)")). The [Segovia Viaduct](/wiki/Segovia_Viaduct "Segovia Viaduct") linked the Royal Alcázar to the southern part of town.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Estatua_de_Atenea_-_C%C3%ADrculo_de_Bellas_Artes_%28Madrid%29.jpg/220px-Estatua_de_Atenea_-_C%C3%ADrculo_de_Bellas_Artes_%28Madrid%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Estatua_de_Atenea_-_C%C3%ADrculo_de_Bellas_Artes_(Madrid).jpg) The [Círculo de Bellas Artes](/wiki/C%C3%ADrculo_de_Bellas_Artes "Círculo de Bellas Artes")

The list of key figures of madrilenian architecture during the 19th and 20th centuries includes authors such as [Narciso Pascual y Colomer](/wiki/Narciso_Pascual_Colomer "Narciso Pascual Colomer"), [Francisco Jareño y Alarcón](/wiki/Francisco_Jare%C3%B1o_y_Alarc%C3%B3n "Francisco Jareño y Alarcón"), [Francisco de Cubas](/wiki/Francisco_de_Cubas "Francisco de Cubas"), [Juan Bautista Lázaro de Diego](/wiki/Juan_Bautista_L%C3%A1zaro_de_Diego "Juan Bautista Lázaro de Diego"), [Ricardo Velázquez Bosco](/wiki/Ricardo_Vel%C3%A1zquez_Bosco "Ricardo Velázquez Bosco"), [Antonio Palacios](/wiki/Antonio_Palacios "Antonio Palacios"), [Secundino Zuazo](/wiki/Secundino_Zuazo "Secundino Zuazo"), [Luis Gutiérrez Soto](/wiki/Luis_Guti%C3%A9rrez_Soto "Luis Gutiérrez Soto"), [Luis Moya Blanco](/w/index.php?title=Luis_Moya_Blanco&action=edit&redlink=1 "Luis Moya Blanco (page does not exist)") \[[es](https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Luis_Moya_Blanco "es:Luis Moya Blanco")\] and [Alejandro de la Sota](/wiki/Alejandro_de_la_Sota_(architect) "Alejandro de la Sota (architect)").^[\[156\]](#cite_note-157)^{#cite_ref-157}

From the mid-19th century until the Civil War, Madrid modernised and built new neighbourhoods and monuments. The expansion of Madrid developed under the [Plan Castro](/wiki/Ensanche "Ensanche"), resulting in the neighbourhoods of [Salamanca](/wiki/Salamanca_(Madrid) "Salamanca (Madrid)"), [Argüelles](/wiki/Moncloa-Aravaca "Moncloa-Aravaca"), and [Chamberí](/wiki/Chamber%C3%AD "Chamberí"). [Arturo Soria](/wiki/Arturo_Soria "Arturo Soria") conceived the [linear city](/wiki/Linear_city_(Soria_design) "Linear city (Soria design)") and built the first few kilometres of the road that bears his name, which embodies the idea. The [Gran Vía](/wiki/Gran_V%C3%ADa_(Madrid) "Gran Vía (Madrid)") was built using different styles that evolved over time: French style, eclectic, art deco, and expressionist. However, [Art Nouveau in Madrid](/wiki/Art_Nouveau_in_Madrid "Art Nouveau in Madrid"), known as *Modernismo* did also develop at the turn of the century, in concert with its appearance elsewhere in Europe, including [Barcelona](/wiki/Barcelona "Barcelona") and [Valencia](/wiki/Valencia "Valencia"). [Antonio Palacios](/wiki/Antonio_Palacios "Antonio Palacios") built a series of buildings inspired by the [Viennese Secession](/wiki/Viennese_Secession "Viennese Secession"), such as the [Palace of Communication](/wiki/Palace_of_Communication "Palace of Communication"), the [Círculo de Bellas Artes](/wiki/C%C3%ADrculo_de_Bellas_Artes "Círculo de Bellas Artes"), and the [Río de La Plata Bank](/wiki/R%C3%ADo_de_La_Plata_Bank "Río de La Plata Bank") (now [Instituto Cervantes](/wiki/Instituto_Cervantes "Instituto Cervantes")). Other notable buildings include the [Bank of Spain](/wiki/Bank_of_Spain "Bank of Spain"), the neo-Gothic [Almudena Cathedral](/wiki/Almudena_Cathedral "Almudena Cathedral"), [Atocha Station](/wiki/Atocha_Station "Atocha Station"), and the Catalan art-nouveau [Palace of Longoria](/wiki/Palace_of_Longoria "Palace of Longoria"). [Las Ventas](/wiki/Las_Ventas "Las Ventas") Bullring was built, as the [Market of San Miguel](/wiki/Market_of_San_Miguel "Market of San Miguel") (Cast-Iron style).
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Edificio_Espa%C3%B1a_-_05.jpg/220px-Edificio_Espa%C3%B1a_-_05.jpg)](/wiki/File:Edificio_Espa%C3%B1a_-_05.jpg) The [Edificio España](/wiki/Edificio_Espa%C3%B1a "Edificio España")

Following the Francoist takeover that ensued the end of Spanish Civil war, architecture experienced an involution, discarding rationalism and, eclecticism notwithstanding, going back to an overall rather "outmoded" architectural language, with the purpose of turning Madrid into a capital worthy of the "Immortal Spain".^[\[157\]](#cite_note-torrus-158)^ Iconic examples of this period include the [Ministry of the Air](/wiki/General_Headquarters_of_the_Air_and_Space_Force "General Headquarters of the Air and Space Force") (a case of [herrerian](/wiki/Herrerian "Herrerian") revival) and the [Edificio España](/wiki/Edificio_Espa%C3%B1a "Edificio España") (presented as the tallest building in Europe when it was inaugurated in 1953).^[\[158\]](#cite_note-159)^^[\[157\]](#cite_note-torrus-158)^ Many of these buildings distinctly combine the use of brick and stone in the façades.^[\[157\]](#cite_note-torrus-158)^ The [Casa Sindical](/wiki/Casa_Sindical "Casa Sindical") marked a breaking point as it was the first to reassume rationalism, although that relinking to modernity was undertaken through the imitation of the Italian Fascist architecture.^[\[157\]](#cite_note-torrus-158)^{#cite_ref-torrus_158-3}

With the advent of Spanish economic development, skyscrapers, such as [Torre Picasso](/wiki/Torre_Picasso "Torre Picasso"), Torres Blancas and Torre BBVA, and the [Gate of Europe](/wiki/Gate_of_Europe "Gate of Europe"), appeared in the late 20th century in the city. During the decade of the 2000s, the four tallest skyscrapers in Spain were built and together form the [Cuatro Torres Business Area](/wiki/Cuatro_Torres_Business_Area "Cuatro Torres Business Area").^[\[159\]](#cite_note-160)^ Terminal 4 at [Madrid-Barajas Airport](/wiki/Madrid-Barajas_Airport "Madrid-Barajas Airport") was inaugurated in 2006 and won several architectural awards. Terminal 4 is one of the world's largest terminal areas^[\[160\]](#cite_note-161)^ and features glass panes and domes in the roof, which allow natural light to pass through.{#cite_ref-161}  

### Museums and cultural centres {#Museums_and_cultural_centres}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit&section=34 "Edit section: Museums and cultural centres")\]  
See also: [List of museums in Madrid](/wiki/List_of_museums_in_Madrid "List of museums in Madrid")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Las_Meninas%2C_by_Diego_Vel%C3%A1zquez%2C_from_Prado_in_Google_Earth.jpg/170px-Las_Meninas%2C_by_Diego_Vel%C3%A1zquez%2C_from_Prado_in_Google_Earth.jpg)](/wiki/File:Las_Meninas,_by_Diego_Vel%C3%A1zquez,_from_Prado_in_Google_Earth.jpg) *[Las Meninas](/wiki/Las_Meninas "Las Meninas")* , by [Diego Velázquez](/wiki/Diego_Vel%C3%A1zquez "Diego Velázquez"), 1656 ([Prado Museum](/wiki/Prado_Museum "Prado Museum"))

Madrid is considered one of the top European destinations concerning art museums. Best known is the [Golden Triangle of Art](/wiki/Golden_Triangle_of_Art "Golden Triangle of Art"), located along the [Paseo del Prado](/wiki/Paseo_del_Prado "Paseo del Prado") and comprising three major museums: the [Prado Museum](/wiki/Museo_del_Prado "Museo del Prado"), the [Reina Sofía Museum](/wiki/Museo_Nacional_Centro_de_Arte_Reina_Sof%C3%ADa "Museo Nacional Centro de Arte Reina Sofía"), and the [Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum](/wiki/Thyssen-Bornemisza_Museum "Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum").

The Prado Museum (*Museo del Prado* ) is a museum and art gallery that features one of the world's finest collections of European art, from the 12th century to the early 19th century, based on the former [Spanish Royal Collection](/wiki/Spanish_Royal_Collection "Spanish Royal Collection"). It has the best collection of artworks by [Goya](/wiki/Francisco_Goya "Francisco Goya"), [Velázquez](/wiki/Diego_Vel%C3%A1zquez "Diego Velázquez"), [El Greco](/wiki/El_Greco "El Greco"), [Rubens](/wiki/Rubens "Rubens"), [Titian](/wiki/Titian "Titian"), [Hieronymus Bosch](/wiki/Hieronymus_Bosch "Hieronymus Bosch"), [José de Ribera](/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_de_Ribera "José de Ribera"), and [Patinir](/wiki/Patinir "Patinir"), as well as works by [Rogier van der Weyden](/wiki/Rogier_van_der_Weyden "Rogier van der Weyden"), [Raphael Sanzio](/wiki/Raphael_Sanzio "Raphael Sanzio"), [Tintoretto](/wiki/Tintoretto "Tintoretto"), [Veronese](/wiki/Paolo_Veronese "Paolo Veronese"), [Caravaggio](/wiki/Caravaggio "Caravaggio"), [Van Dyck](/wiki/Van_Dyck "Van Dyck"), [Albrecht Dürer](/wiki/Albrecht_D%C3%BCrer "Albrecht Dürer"), [Claude Lorrain](/wiki/Claude_Lorrain "Claude Lorrain"), [Murillo](/wiki/Bartolom%C3%A9_Esteban_Murillo "Bartolomé Esteban Murillo"), and [Zurbarán](/wiki/Zurbar%C3%A1n "Zurbarán"), among others. Some of the standout works exhibited at the museum include *[Las Meninas](/wiki/Las_Meninas "Las Meninas")* , *[La maja vestida](/wiki/La_maja_vestida "La maja vestida")* , *[La maja desnuda](/wiki/La_maja_desnuda "La maja desnuda")* , *[The Garden of Earthly Delights](/wiki/The_Garden_of_Earthly_Delights "The Garden of Earthly Delights")* , *[The Immaculate Conception](/wiki/The_Immaculate_Conception_(Tiepolo) "The Immaculate Conception (Tiepolo)")* and *[The Judgement of Paris](/wiki/The_Judgement_of_Paris_(Rubens) "The Judgement of Paris (Rubens)")*.

The Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum (*Museo Thyssen-Bornemisza* ) is an art museum that fills the historical gaps in its counterparts' collections: in the Prado's case, this includes Italian primitives and works from the [English](/wiki/English_art "English art"), [Dutch](/wiki/Dutch_School_(painting) "Dutch School (painting)"), and German schools, while in the case of the Reina Sofía, the Thyssen-Bornemisza collection, once the second largest private collection in the world after the British [Royal Collection](/wiki/Royal_Collection "Royal Collection"),^[\[161\]](#cite_note-nyt-obit-162)^ includes [Impressionists](/wiki/Impressionist "Impressionist"), [Expressionists](/wiki/Expressionist "Expressionist"), and European and American paintings from the second half of the 20th century, with over 1,600 paintings.^[\[162\]](#cite_note-163)^{#cite_ref-163}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Edificio_Sabatini._Museo_Nacional_Centro_de_Arte_Reina_Sof%C3%ADa.jpg/220px-Edificio_Sabatini._Museo_Nacional_Centro_de_Arte_Reina_Sof%C3%ADa.jpg)](/wiki/File:Edificio_Sabatini._Museo_Nacional_Centro_de_Arte_Reina_Sof%C3%ADa.jpg) [Queen Sofía National Museum Art Centre](/wiki/Museo_Nacional_Centro_de_Arte_Reina_Sof%C3%ADa "Museo Nacional Centro de Arte Reina Sofía")

The Reina Sofía National Art Museum (*Museo Nacional Centro de Arte Reina Sofía* ; MNCARS) is Madrid's national museum of [20th-century art](/wiki/20th-century_art "20th-century art") and houses [Pablo Picasso](/wiki/Pablo_Picasso "Pablo Picasso")'s 1937 anti-war masterpiece, *[Guernica](/wiki/Guernica_(painting) "Guernica (painting)")* . Other highlights of the museum, which is mainly dedicated to Spanish art, include excellent collections of Spain's greatest 20th-century masters including [Salvador Dalí](/wiki/Salvador_Dal%C3%AD "Salvador Dalí"), [Joan Miró](/wiki/Joan_Mir%C3%B3 "Joan Miró"), Picasso, [Juan Gris](/wiki/Juan_Gris "Juan Gris"), and [Julio González](/wiki/Julio_Gonz%C3%A1lez_(sculptor) "Julio González (sculptor)"). The Reina Sofía also hosts a free-access art library.^[\[163\]](#cite_note-164)^{#cite_ref-164}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Museo_Arqueol%C3%B3gico_Nacional_%2834583977144%29.jpg/220px-Museo_Arqueol%C3%B3gico_Nacional_%2834583977144%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Museo_Arqueol%C3%B3gico_Nacional_(34583977144).jpg) Cloister in the [National Archaeological Museum](/wiki/National_Archaeological_Museum_(Madrid) "National Archaeological Museum (Madrid)") (MAN) showcasing prehistoric items from the Iberian Peninsula, including the [Mausoleum of Pozo Moro](/wiki/Mausoleum_of_Pozo_Moro "Mausoleum of Pozo Moro")

The [National Archaeological Museum of Madrid](/wiki/National_Archaeological_Museum_(Madrid) "National Archaeological Museum (Madrid)") (*Museo Arqueológico Nacional* ) shows archaeological finds from [Prehistory](/wiki/Prehistory "Prehistory") to the 19th century (including Roman mosaics, Greek ceramics, Islamic art and Romanesque art), especially from the Iberian Peninsula, distributed over three floors. An iconic item in the museum is the [Lady of Elche](/wiki/Lady_of_Elche "Lady of Elche"), an Iberian bust from the 4th century BC. Other major pieces include the [Lady of Baza](/wiki/Lady_of_Baza "Lady of Baza"), the [Lady of Cerro de los Santos](/wiki/Lady_of_Cerro_de_los_Santos "Lady of Cerro de los Santos"), the [Lady of Ibiza](/wiki/Lady_of_Ibiza "Lady of Ibiza"), the [Bicha of Balazote](/wiki/Bicha_of_Balazote "Bicha of Balazote"), the [Treasure of Guarrazar](/wiki/Treasure_of_Guarrazar "Treasure of Guarrazar"), the [Pyxis of Zamora](/wiki/Pyxis_of_Zamora "Pyxis of Zamora"), the [Mausoleum of Pozo Moro](/wiki/Mausoleum_of_Pozo_Moro "Mausoleum of Pozo Moro") and a [napier's bones](/wiki/Napier%27s_bones "Napier's bones"). In addition, the museum has a reproduction of the polychromatic paintings in the [Altamira Cave](/wiki/Altamira_Cave "Altamira Cave").

The [Royal Academy of Fine Arts of San Fernando](/wiki/Real_Academia_de_Bellas_Artes_de_San_Fernando "Real Academia de Bellas Artes de San Fernando") (*Real Academia de Bellas Artes de San Fernando* ) houses a fine art collection of paintings ranging from the 15th to 20th centuries. The academy is also the headquarters of the Madrid Academy of Art.^[\[n. 2\]](#cite_note-167)^{#cite_ref-167}

[CaixaForum Madrid](/wiki/CaixaForum_Madrid "CaixaForum Madrid") is a post-modern art gallery in the centre of Madrid, next to the Prado Museum.^[\[166\]](#cite_note-168)^{#cite_ref-168}

The [Royal Palace of Madrid](/wiki/Royal_Palace_of_Madrid "Royal Palace of Madrid"), a massive building characterised by its luxurious rooms, houses rich collections of armours and weapons, as well as the most comprehensive collection of [Stradivarius](/wiki/Antonio_Stradivari "Antonio Stradivari") in the world.^[\[167\]](#cite_note-169)^ The [Museo de las Colecciones Reales](/wiki/Museo_de_las_Colecciones_Reales "Museo de las Colecciones Reales") is a future museum intended to host the most outstanding pieces of the Royal Collections part of the [Patrimonio Nacional](/wiki/Patrimonio_Nacional "Patrimonio Nacional"). Located next to the Royal Palace and the Almudena, Patrimonio Nacional has tentatively scheduled its opening for 2021.^[\[168\]](#cite_note-170)^{#cite_ref-170}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Museo_de_Am%C3%A9rica_%28Madrid%29_03.jpg/220px-Museo_de_Am%C3%A9rica_%28Madrid%29_03.jpg)](/wiki/File:Museo_de_Am%C3%A9rica_(Madrid)_03.jpg) [Museo de América](/wiki/Museo_de_Am%C3%A9rica "Museo de América")

The [Museum of the Americas](/wiki/Museum_of_the_Americas_(Madrid) "Museum of the Americas (Madrid)") (*Museo de América* ) is a national museum that holds artistic, archaeological, and ethnographic collections from the [Americas](/wiki/Americas "Americas"), ranging from the [Paleolithic](/wiki/Paleolithic "Paleolithic") period to the present day.^[\[169\]](#cite_note-museodeamerica1-171)^{#cite_ref-museodeamerica1_171-0}

Other notable museums include the [National Museum of Natural Sciences](/wiki/Museo_Nacional_de_Ciencias_Naturales "Museo Nacional de Ciencias Naturales") (the Spain's national museum of [natural history](/wiki/Natural_history "Natural history")),^[\[170\]](#cite_note-autogenerated2-172)^ the [Naval Museum](/wiki/Museo_Naval_de_Madrid "Museo Naval de Madrid"),^[\[171\]](#cite_note-173)^ the [Convent of Las Descalzas Reales](/wiki/Convent_of_Las_Descalzas_Reales "Convent of Las Descalzas Reales") (with many works of Renaissance and Baroque art, and [Brussels tapestries](/wiki/Brussels_tapestry "Brussels tapestry") inspired by paintings of Rubens),^[\[172\]](#cite_note-patrimonionacional1-174)^ the [Museum of Lázaro Galdiano](/wiki/Museum_of_L%C3%A1zaro_Galdiano "Museum of Lázaro Galdiano") (housing a collection specialising in decorative arts, featuring a collection of weapons that features the sword of Pope [Innocent VIII](/wiki/Innocent_VIII "Innocent VIII")),^[\[173\]](#cite_note-autogenerated3-175)^ the [National Museum of Decorative Arts](/wiki/Museo_Nacional_de_Artes_Decorativas "Museo Nacional de Artes Decorativas"),^[\[174\]](#cite_note-176)^ the [National Museum of Romanticism](/wiki/Museum_of_Romanticism_(Madrid) "Museum of Romanticism (Madrid)") (focused on 19th century Romanticism),^[\[175\]](#cite_note-177)^ the [Museum Cerralbo](/wiki/Museum_Cerralbo "Museum Cerralbo"),^[\[176\]](#cite_note-178)^ the [National Museum of Anthropology](/wiki/Museo_Nacional_de_Antropolog%C3%ADa_(Madrid) "Museo Nacional de Antropología (Madrid)") (featuring as highlight a [Guanche](/wiki/Guanches "Guanches") mummy from [Tenerife](/wiki/Tenerife "Tenerife")),^[\[177\]](#cite_note-179)^ the [Sorolla Museum](/wiki/Sorolla_Museum "Sorolla Museum") (focused in the namesake Valencian Impressionist painter,^[\[178\]](#cite_note-museosorolla1-180)^ also including sculptures by [Auguste Rodin](/wiki/Auguste_Rodin "Auguste Rodin"), part of Sorolla's personal effects),^[\[179\]](#cite_note-museosorolla2-181)^ or the [History Museum of Madrid](/wiki/Museo_de_Historia_de_Madrid "Museo de Historia de Madrid") (housing pieces related to the local history of Madrid), the [Wax Museum of Madrid](/wiki/Wax_Museum_of_Madrid "Wax Museum of Madrid"), and the [Railway Museum](/wiki/Railway_Museum_(Madrid) "Railway Museum (Madrid)") (located in the building that was once the Delicias Station).{#cite_ref-museosorolla2_181-0}

Major cultural centres in the city include the [Fine Arts Circle](/wiki/C%C3%ADrculo_de_Bellas_Artes "Círculo de Bellas Artes") (one of Madrid's oldest arts centres and one of the most important private cultural centres in Europe, hosting exhibitions, shows, film screenings, conferences and workshops), the [Conde Duque cultural centre](/wiki/Cuartel_del_Conde-Duque "Cuartel del Conde-Duque") or the [Matadero Madrid](/wiki/Matadero_Madrid "Matadero Madrid"), a cultural complex (formerly an abattoir) located by the river Manzanares. The Matadero, created in 2006 with the aim of "promoting research, production, learning, and diffusion of creative works and contemporary thought in all their manifestations", is considered the third most valued cultural institution in Madrid among art professionals.^[\[180\]](#cite_note-182)^{#cite_ref-182}  

### Language {#Language}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit&section=35 "Edit section: Language")\]

The usual language in Madrid is [Peninsular Spanish](/wiki/Peninsular_Spanish "Peninsular Spanish"). It is in the transition between northern and southern dialects. Typical features are:

* *[Yeísmo](/wiki/Ye%C3%ADsmo "Yeísmo")*, *calló* and *cayó* sound alike among all social classes.^[\[181\]](#cite_note-Zamora-183)^ According to [Alonso Zamora Vicente](/w/index.php?title=Alonso_Zamora_Vicente&action=edit&redlink=1 "Alonso Zamora Vicente (page does not exist)") \[[es](https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alonso_Zamora_Vicente "es:Alonso Zamora Vicente")\], *yeísmo* has extended from Madrid across Spain.^[\[181\]](#cite_note-Zamora-183)^{#cite_ref-Zamora_183-1}
* Aspiration of [implosive](/wiki/Implosive "Implosive") /s/.^[\[182\]](#cite_note-Quilis-184)^{#cite_ref-Quilis_184-0}
* Frequent ellision of final /d/ ([\[maˈðɾi\]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Spanish "Help:IPA/Spanish")) and devoicing /θ/ ([\[maˈðɾiθ\]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Spanish "Help:IPA/Spanish") [](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/d/d0/ES-pe_-_Madrid.ogg/ES-pe_-_Madrid.ogg.mp3 "Play audio")^[ⓘ](/wiki/File:ES-pe_-_Madrid.ogg "File:ES-pe - Madrid.ogg")^) coexist with the standard preservation ([\[maˈðɾið\]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Spanish "Help:IPA/Spanish") [](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/7/75/Pronunciation_of_Madrid_in_Spanish.ogg/Pronunciation_of_Madrid_in_Spanish.ogg.mp3 "Play audio")^[ⓘ](/wiki/File:Pronunciation_of_Madrid_in_Spanish.ogg "File:Pronunciation of Madrid in Spanish.ogg")^) realised with varying degrees of relaxation.^[\[8\]](#cite_note-Molina_Martos_2016-8)^{#cite_ref-Molina_Martos_2016_8-1}
* *[leísmo](/wiki/Le%C3%ADsmo "Leísmo")*, *[laísmo](/wiki/La%C3%ADsmo "Laísmo")* and *[loísmo](/wiki/Lo%C3%ADsmo "Loísmo")*. According to [Samuel Gili Gaya](/w/index.php?title=Samuel_Gili_Gaya&action=edit&redlink=1 "Samuel Gili Gaya (page does not exist)") \[[es](https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Samuel_Gili_Gaya "es:Samuel Gili Gaya")\], in Madrid speech, pronoun *le* is specialized in the masculine and pronoun *la* in the feminine, for direct and indirect objects.^[\[183\]](#cite_note-Gili-185)^{#cite_ref-Gili_185-0}

The arrival to Madrid of a substantial number of immigrants from [Latin America](/wiki/Latin_America "Latin America") (such as [Ecuadorians](/wiki/Ecuadorians "Ecuadorians")) has induced processes of dialectal convergence and divergence in the city.^[\[184\]](#cite_note-186)^{#cite_ref-186}

In the 1970s and 1980s, Madrid youth created their own slang, [Cheli](/wiki/Cheli "Cheli").^[\[185\]](#cite_note-Buzek-187)^{#cite_ref-Buzek_187-0}  

### Literature {#Literature}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit&section=36 "Edit section: Literature")\]

Madrid has been one of the great centres of [Spanish literature](/wiki/Spanish_literature "Spanish literature"). Some of the most distinguished writers of the [Spanish Golden Century](/wiki/Spanish_Golden_Age "Spanish Golden Age") were born in Madrid, including [Lope de Vega](/wiki/Lope_de_Vega "Lope de Vega") (author of *[Fuenteovejuna](/wiki/Fuenteovejuna "Fuenteovejuna")* and *[The Dog in the Manger](/wiki/The_Dog_in_the_Manger_(play) "The Dog in the Manger (play)")* ), who reformed the Spanish theatre, a project continued by [Calderon de la Barca](/wiki/Calderon_de_la_Barca "Calderon de la Barca") (author of *[Life is a Dream](/wiki/Life_is_a_Dream "Life is a Dream")* ). [Francisco de Quevedo](/wiki/Francisco_de_Quevedo "Francisco de Quevedo"), who criticised the Spanish society of his day, and author of *[El Buscón](/wiki/El_Busc%C3%B3n "El Buscón")* , and [Tirso de Molina](/wiki/Tirso_de_Molina "Tirso de Molina"), who created the character [Don Juan](/wiki/Don_Juan "Don Juan"), were born in Madrid. [Cervantes](/wiki/Miguel_de_Cervantes "Miguel de Cervantes") and [Góngora](/wiki/Luis_de_G%C3%B3ngora "Luis de Góngora") also lived in the city, although they were not born there. The Madrid homes of Lope de Vega, Quevedo, Gongora, and Cervantes still exist, and they are all in the Barrio de las Letras (Literary Neighborhood). Other writers born in Madrid in later centuries have been [Leandro Fernandez de Moratín](/wiki/Leandro_Fernandez_de_Morat%C3%ADn "Leandro Fernandez de Moratín"), [Mariano José de Larra](/wiki/Mariano_Jos%C3%A9_de_Larra "Mariano José de Larra"), [Jose de Echegaray](/wiki/Jose_de_Echegaray "Jose de Echegaray") ([Nobel Prize in Literature](/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Literature "Nobel Prize in Literature")), [Ramón Gómez de la Serna](/wiki/Ram%C3%B3n_G%C3%B3mez_de_la_Serna "Ramón Gómez de la Serna"), [Dámaso Alonso](/wiki/D%C3%A1maso_Alonso "Dámaso Alonso"), [Enrique Jardiel Poncela](/wiki/Enrique_Jardiel_Poncela "Enrique Jardiel Poncela") and [Pedro Salinas](/wiki/Pedro_Salinas "Pedro Salinas").

The "Barrio de las Letras" owes its name to the intense literary activity taking place there during the 16th and 17th centuries. Some of the most prominent writers of the [Spanish Golden Age](/wiki/Spanish_Golden_Age "Spanish Golden Age") lived here, such as [Lope de Vega](/wiki/Lope_de_Vega "Lope de Vega"), [Quevedo](/wiki/Francisco_de_Quevedo "Francisco de Quevedo"), and [Góngora](/wiki/Luis_de_G%C3%B3ngora "Luis de Góngora"), and it contained the Cruz and Príncipe Theatres, two of the most important in Spain. At 87 Calle de Atocha, on the northern end of the neighborhood, was the printing house of [Juan de la Cuesta](/wiki/Juan_de_la_Cuesta "Juan de la Cuesta"), where the first edition of [Don Quixote](/wiki/Don_Quixote "Don Quixote") was typeset and printed in 1604. Most of the literary routes are articulated^\[*[further explanation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify "Wikipedia:Please clarify")*\]^ along the Barrio de las Letras, where you can find scenes from novels of the [Siglo de Oro](/wiki/Siglo_de_Oro "Siglo de Oro") and more recent works like "[Bohemian Lights](/wiki/Bohemian_Lights "Bohemian Lights")".^\[*[further explanation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify "Wikipedia:Please clarify")*\]^ Although born in [Las Palmas de Gran Canaria](/wiki/Las_Palmas_de_Gran_Canaria "Las Palmas de Gran Canaria"), [realist](/wiki/Spanish_Realist_literature "Spanish Realist literature") writer [Benito Pérez Galdós](/wiki/Benito_P%C3%A9rez_Gald%C3%B3s "Benito Pérez Galdós") made Madrid the setting for many of his stories; there is a giidebook to the Madrid of Galdós (*Madrid galdosiano* ).^[\[186\]](#cite_note-188)^{#cite_ref-188}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/BNE_-_panoramio.jpg/220px-BNE_-_panoramio.jpg)](/wiki/File:BNE_-_panoramio.jpg) Interior of the National Library of Spain

Madrid is home to the [Royal Spanish Academy](/wiki/Royal_Spanish_Academy "Royal Spanish Academy"), the Royal Academy of the Spanish Language, which governs, with statutory authority, over Spanish,^[\[187\]](#cite_note-189)^ preparing, publishing, and updating authoritative reference works on it. The academy's motto (*lema* , in Spanish) states its purpose: it cleans the language, stabilizes it, and gives it brilliance ("Limpia, fija y da resplendor"). Madrid is also home to another international cultural institution, the [Instituto Cervantes](/wiki/Instituto_Cervantes "Instituto Cervantes"), whose task is the promotion and teaching of the [Spanish language](/wiki/Spanish_language "Spanish language") as well as the dissemination of the culture of [Spain](/wiki/Spain "Spain") and [Hispanic America](/wiki/Hispanic_America "Hispanic America"). The [National Library of Spain](/wiki/Biblioteca_Nacional_de_Espa%C3%B1a "Biblioteca Nacional de España") is the largest major public library in Spain. The library's collection consists of more than 26,000,000 items, including 15,000,000 books and other printed materials, 30,000 manuscripts, 143,000 newspapers and serials, 4,500,000 graphic materials, 510,000 music scores, 500,000 maps, 600,000 sound recording, 90,000 audiovisuals, 90,000 electronic documents, and more than 500,000 microforms.^[\[188\]](#cite_note-190)^{#cite_ref-190}  

### Cuisine {#Cuisine}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit&section=37 "Edit section: Cuisine")\]  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/BocadilloCalamaresAtocha_%28cropped%29.JPG/220px-BocadilloCalamaresAtocha_%28cropped%29.JPG)](/wiki/File:BocadilloCalamaresAtocha_(cropped).JPG)  
Three [squid sandwiches](/wiki/Squid_sandwich "Squid sandwich")  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/Patatas_bravas_madrid_%28cropped%29.jpg/220px-Patatas_bravas_madrid_%28cropped%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Patatas_bravas_madrid_(cropped).jpg)  
*[Patatas bravas](/wiki/Patatas_bravas "Patatas bravas")* , a very common bar snack served as *[tapa](/wiki/Tapas "Tapas")*

The Madrilenian cuisine has received plenty of influences from other regions of Spain and its own identity actually relies in its ability to assimilate elements from the immigration.^[\[189\]](#cite_note-5d-191)^{#cite_ref-5d_191-0}

The *[cocido madrileño](/wiki/Cocido_madrile%C3%B1o "Cocido madrileño")* , a [chickpea](/wiki/Chickpea "Chickpea")-based [stew](/wiki/Stew "Stew"), is one of the most emblematic dishes of the Madrilenian cuisine.^[\[190\]](#cite_note-192)^ The *[callos a la madrileña](/w/index.php?title=Callos_a_la_madrile%C3%B1a&action=edit&redlink=1 "Callos a la madrileña (page does not exist)") \[[es](https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/callos_a_la_madrile%C3%B1a "es:callos a la madrileña")\]* is another traditional winter specialty, usually made of cattle [tripes](/wiki/Tripe "Tripe").^[\[191\]](#cite_note-Madridiario-2020-193)^ Other [offal](/wiki/Offal "Offal") dishes typical in the city include the *[gallinejas](/w/index.php?title=Gallinejas&action=edit&redlink=1 "Gallinejas (page does not exist)") \[[es](https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/gallinejas "es:gallinejas")\]* ^[\[191\]](#cite_note-Madridiario-2020-193)^ or grilled [pig's ear](/wiki/Pig%27s_ear_(food) "Pig's ear (food)").^[\[192\]](#cite_note-194)^ Fried [squid](/wiki/Squid "Squid") has become a culinary specialty in Madrid, often consumed in sandwich as [*bocata de calamares*](/wiki/Squid_sandwich "Squid sandwich").^[\[191\]](#cite_note-Madridiario-2020-193)^{#cite_ref-Madridiario-2020_193-2}

Other generic dishes commonly accepted as part of the Madrilenian cuisine include the *[potaje](/wiki/Potaje "Potaje")* , the *[sopa de ajo](/wiki/Garlic_soup "Garlic soup")* (Garlic soup), the [Spanish omelette](/wiki/Spanish_omelette "Spanish omelette"), the *[besugo a la madrileña](/w/index.php?title=Besugo_a_la_madrile%C3%B1a&action=edit&redlink=1 "Besugo a la madrileña (page does not exist)") \[[es](https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/besugo_a_la_madrile%C3%B1a "es:besugo a la madrileña")\]* ([bream](/wiki/Bream "Bream")), *[caracoles a la madrileña](/w/index.php?title=Caracoles_a_la_madrile%C3%B1a&action=edit&redlink=1 "Caracoles a la madrileña (page does not exist)") \[[es](https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/caracoles_a_la_madrile%C3%B1a "es:caracoles a la madrileña")\]* ([snails](/wiki/Snail "Snail"), sp. *[Cornu aspersum](/wiki/Cornu_aspersum "Cornu aspersum")* ) or the [soldaditos de Pavía](/wiki/Soldaditos_de_Pav%C3%ADa "Soldaditos de Pavía"), the *[patatas bravas](/wiki/Patatas_bravas "Patatas bravas")* (consumed as snack in bars) or the *gallina en [pepitoria](/w/index.php?title=Pepitoria&action=edit&redlink=1 "Pepitoria (page does not exist)") \[[es](https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/pepitoria "es:pepitoria")\]* (hen or chicken cooked with the yolk of [hard-boiled eggs](/wiki/Boiled_egg "Boiled egg") and [almonds](/wiki/Almond "Almond")) to name a few.^[\[193\]](#cite_note-195)^^[\[194\]](#cite_note-davalos-196)^^[\[189\]](#cite_note-5d-191)^{#cite_ref-5d_191-1}

Traditional desserts include *[torrijas](/wiki/French_toast "French toast")* (a variant of French toast consumed during Easter)^[\[191\]](#cite_note-Madridiario-2020-193)^^[\[195\]](#cite_note-197)^ and *[bartolillos](/w/index.php?title=Bartolillos&action=edit&redlink=1 "Bartolillos (page does not exist)") \[[es](https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/bartolillos "es:bartolillos")\]* .^[\[194\]](#cite_note-davalos-196)^{#cite_ref-davalos_196-1}  
See also: [Cuisine of the Community of Madrid](/wiki/Cuisine_of_the_Community_of_Madrid "Cuisine of the Community of Madrid")  

### Nightlife {#Nightlife}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit&section=38 "Edit section: Nightlife")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Madrid_%2828228858839%29.jpg/220px-Madrid_%2828228858839%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Madrid_(28228858839).jpg) Nightlife in the Centro District

Madrid is an international hub of highly active and diverse [nightlife](/wiki/Nightlife "Nightlife") with [bars](/wiki/Bar_(establishment) "Bar (establishment)"), dance bars and [nightclubs](/wiki/Nightclub "Nightclub") staying open well past midnight.^[\[196\]](#cite_note-198)^ Madrid is reputed to have a "vibrant [nightlife](/wiki/Nightlife "Nightlife")".^[\[197\]](#cite_note-cnn-199)^ Some of the highlight bustling locations include the surroundings of the [Plaza de Santa Ana](/wiki/Plaza_de_Santa_Ana "Plaza de Santa Ana"), [Malasaña](/wiki/Malasa%C3%B1a "Malasaña") and La Latina (particularly near the [Cava Baja](/w/index.php?title=Calle_de_la_Cava_Baja&action=edit&redlink=1 "Calle de la Cava Baja (page does not exist)") \[[es](https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Calle_de_la_Cava_Baja "es:Calle de la Cava Baja")\]).^[\[197\]](#cite_note-cnn-199)^ It is one of the city's main attractions with tapas bars, cocktail bars, clubs, jazz lounges, live music venues and flamenco theatres. Most nightclubs liven up by 1:30
a.m.and stay open until at least 6
a.m.^[\[197\]](#cite_note-cnn-199)^{#cite_ref-cnn_199-2}

Nightlife flourished in the 1980s while Madrid's mayor [Enrique Tierno Galván](/wiki/Enrique_Tierno_Galv%C3%A1n "Enrique Tierno Galván") ([PSOE](/wiki/Spanish_Socialist_Workers%27_Party "Spanish Socialist Workers' Party")) was in office, nurturing the cultural-musical movement known as *[La Movida](/wiki/La_Movida_Madrile%C3%B1a "La Movida Madrileña")* .^[\[198\]](#cite_note-200)^ Nowadays, the [Malasaña](/wiki/Malasa%C3%B1a "Malasaña") area is known for its [alternative](/wiki/Independent_music "Independent music") scene.{#cite_ref-200}

The area of [Chueca](/wiki/Chueca,_Madrid "Chueca, Madrid") has also become a hot spot in the Madrilenian nightlife, especially for the gay population. Chueca is known as gay quarter, comparable to the [Castro District](/wiki/Castro_District,_San_Francisco "Castro District, San Francisco") in San Francisco.^[\[199\]](#cite_note-201)^{#cite_ref-201}  
See also: [La Movida Madrileña](/wiki/La_Movida_Madrile%C3%B1a "La Movida Madrileña")  

### Bohemian culture {#Bohemian_culture}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit&section=39 "Edit section: Bohemian culture")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Madrid_%2848046139067%29.jpg/220px-Madrid_%2848046139067%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Madrid_(48046139067).jpg) Nights in [Malasaña](/wiki/Malasa%C3%B1a "Malasaña") are often crowded.

The city has venues for performing alternative art and expressive art. They are mostly located in the centre of the city, including in Ópera, Antón Martín, [Chueca](/wiki/Chueca,_Madrid "Chueca, Madrid") and [Malasaña](/wiki/Malasa%C3%B1a "Malasaña"). There are also several festivals in Madrid, including the Festival of Alternative Art, and the Festival of the Alternative Scene.^[\[200\]](#cite_note-202)^^[\[201\]](#cite_note-203)^^[\[202\]](#cite_note-204)^^[\[203\]](#cite_note-205)^{#cite_ref-205}

The neighbourhood of [Malasaña](/wiki/Malasa%C3%B1a "Malasaña"), as well as Antón Martín and [Lavapiés](/wiki/Lavapi%C3%A9s "Lavapiés"), hosts several bohemian cafés/galleries. These cafés are typified with period or retro furniture or furniture found on the street, a colourful, nontraditional atmosphere inside, and usually art displayed each month by a new artist, often for sale. Cafés include the retro café *Lolina* and bohemian cafés *La Ida* , *La Paca* and *Café de la Luz* in Malasaña, *La Piola* in Huertas and *Café Olmo* and *Aguardiente* in Lavapiés.

In the neighbourhood of Lavapiés, there are also "hidden houses", which are illegal bars or abandoned spaces where concerts, poetry readings and^[\[204\]](#cite_note-206)^^[\[205\]](#cite_note-207)^^[\[206\]](#cite_note-208)^ the famous Spanish *[botellón](/wiki/Botell%C3%B3n "Botellón")* (a street party or gathering that is now illegal but rarely stopped).{#cite_ref-208}  

### Classical music and opera {#Classical_music_and_opera}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit&section=40 "Edit section: Classical music and opera")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Palco_TeatroReal.jpg/220px-Palco_TeatroReal.jpg)](/wiki/File:Palco_TeatroReal.jpg) The [Teatro Real](/wiki/Teatro_Real "Teatro Real")

The [Auditorio Nacional de Música](/wiki/National_Auditorium_of_Music "National Auditorium of Music") ^[\[207\]](#cite_note-209)^ is the main venue for classical music concerts in Madrid. It is home to the [Spanish National Orchestra](/wiki/Spanish_National_Orchestra "Spanish National Orchestra"), the [Chamartín Symphony Orchestra](/wiki/Chamart%C3%ADn_Symphony_Orchestra "Chamartín Symphony Orchestra")^[\[208\]](#cite_note-Orquesta_Sinfónica_Chamartín-Historia_(in_Spanish)-210)^ and the venue for the symphonic concerts of the [Community of Madrid Orchestra](/wiki/Community_of_Madrid_Orchestra "Community of Madrid Orchestra") and the [Madrid Symphony Orchestra](/wiki/Madrid_Symphony_Orchestra "Madrid Symphony Orchestra"). It is also the principal venue for orchestras on tour playing in Madrid.{#cite_ref-Orquesta_Sinfónica_Chamartín-Historia_(in_Spanish)_210-0}

The [Teatro Real](/wiki/Teatro_Real "Teatro Real") is the main opera house in Madrid, located just in front of the [Royal Palace](/wiki/Royal_Palace_of_Madrid "Royal Palace of Madrid"), and its resident orchestra is the [Madrid Symphony Orchestra](/wiki/Madrid_Symphony_Orchestra "Madrid Symphony Orchestra").^[\[209\]](#cite_note-211)^ The theatre stages around seventeen opera titles (both own productions and co-productions with other major European opera houses) per year, as well as two or three major ballets and several recitals.{#cite_ref-211}

The [Teatro de la Zarzuela](/wiki/Teatro_de_la_Zarzuela "Teatro de la Zarzuela") is mainly devoted to [Zarzuela](/wiki/Zarzuela "Zarzuela") (the Spanish traditional musical theatre genre), as well as [operetta](/wiki/Operetta "Operetta") and [recitals](/wiki/Recital "Recital").^[\[210\]](#cite_note-212)^^[\[211\]](#cite_note-213)^ The resident orchestra of the theatre is the [Community of Madrid Orchestra](/wiki/Community_of_Madrid_Orchestra "Community of Madrid Orchestra").{#cite_ref-213}

The [Teatro Monumental](/wiki/Teatro_Monumental "Teatro Monumental") is the concert venue of the [RTVE Symphony Orchestra](/wiki/RTVE_Symphony_Orchestra "RTVE Symphony Orchestra").^[\[212\]](#cite_note-214)^{#cite_ref-214}

Other concert venues for classical music are the Fundación Joan March and the [Auditorio 400](/wiki/Museo_Nacional_Centro_de_Arte_Reina_Sof%C3%ADa "Museo Nacional Centro de Arte Reina Sofía"), devoted to contemporary music.  

### Feasts and festivals {#Feasts_and_festivals}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit&section=41 "Edit section: Feasts and festivals")\]  

#### San Isidro {#San_Isidro}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit&section=42 "Edit section: San Isidro")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Madrid_-_Fiestas_de_San_Isidro_-_20070515-45.jpg/220px-Madrid_-_Fiestas_de_San_Isidro_-_20070515-45.jpg)](/wiki/File:Madrid_-_Fiestas_de_San_Isidro_-_20070515-45.jpg) Festivities of San Isidro Labrador in the *pradera*, 2007

The local feast par excellence is the Day of [Isidore the Laborer](/wiki/Isidore_the_Laborer "Isidore the Laborer") (*San Isidro Labrador* ), the patron Saint of Madrid, celebrated on 15 May. It is a [public holiday](/wiki/Public_holiday "Public holiday"). According to tradition, Isidro was a farmworker and well manufacturer born in Madrid in the late 11th century, who lived a pious life and whose corpse was reportedly found to be [incorrupt](/wiki/Incorruptibility "Incorruptibility") in 1212. Already very popular among the madrilenian people, as Madrid became the capital of the Hispanic Monarchy in 1561 the city council pulled efforts to promote his canonization; the process started in 1562.^[\[213\]](#cite_note-215)^ Isidro was beatified in 1619 and the feast day set on 15 May^[\[214\]](#cite_note-216)^ (he was finally canonized in 1622).^[\[215\]](#cite_note-217)^{#cite_ref-217}

On 15 May the Madrilenian people gather around the [Hermitage of San Isidro](/w/index.php?title=Hermitage_of_San_Isidro&action=edit&redlink=1 "Hermitage of San Isidro (page does not exist)") \[[es](https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ermita_de_San_Isidro_(Madrid) "es:Ermita de San Isidro (Madrid)")\] and the [Prairie of San Isidro](/w/index.php?title=Park_of_San_Isidro&action=edit&redlink=1 "Park of San Isidro (page does not exist)") \[[es](https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parque_de_San_Isidro "es:Parque de San Isidro")\] (on the right-bank of the [Manzanares](/wiki/Manzanares_River "Manzanares River")) often dressed with checkered caps (*[parpusas](/w/index.php?title=Parpusa&action=edit&redlink=1 "Parpusa (page does not exist)") \[[es](https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parpusa "es:Parpusa")\]* ) and kerchiefs (*safos* )^[\[216\]](#cite_note-218)^ characteristic of the [chulapos](/wiki/Chulapo "Chulapo") and chulapas, dancing *[chotis](/wiki/Schottische "Schottische")* and *[pasodobles](/wiki/Pasodoble "Pasodoble")* , eating *rosquillas* and *barquillos* .^[\[217\]](#cite_note-219)^{#cite_ref-219}  

#### LGBT pride {#LGBT_pride}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit&section=43 "Edit section: LGBT pride")\]  
Main article: [Madrid Pride](/wiki/Madrid_Pride "Madrid Pride")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/WorldPride_2017_-_Madrid_-_Carrera_de_tacones_-_170629_180856.jpg/220px-WorldPride_2017_-_Madrid_-_Carrera_de_tacones_-_170629_180856.jpg)](/wiki/File:WorldPride_2017_-_Madrid_-_Carrera_de_tacones_-_170629_180856.jpg) High heels race in WorldPride Madrid 2017

The Madrilenian LGBT Pride has grown to become the event bringing the most people together in the city each year^[\[218\]](#cite_note-220)^ as well as one of the most important Pride celebrations worldwide.^[\[219\]](#cite_note-221)^{#cite_ref-221}

Madrid's Pride Parade began in 1977, in the Chueca neighbourhood, which also marked the beginning of the gay, lesbian, transgender, and bisexual rights movement after being repressed for forty years in a dictatorship.^[\[220\]](#cite_note-MADO-2017-222)^ This claiming of LGBT rights has allowed the Pride Parade in Madrid to grow year after year, becoming one of the best in the world. In 2007, this was recognised by the European Pride Organisers Association (EPOA) when Madrid hosted [EuroPride](/wiki/EuroPride "EuroPride"). It was hailed by the then President of the EPOA as "the best EuroPride in history".^[\[221\]](#cite_note-MADO-2016-223)^ In 2017, Madrid celebrated the 40th anniversary of their first Pride Parade by hosting the WorldPride Madrid 2017. Numerous conferences, seminars and workshops as well as cultural and sports activities took place at the festival, the event being a "kids and family pride" and a source of education. More than one million people attended the pride's central march.^[\[222\]](#cite_note-224)^ The main purpose of the celebration was presenting Madrid and the Spanish society in general as a multicultural, diverse, and tolerant community.^[\[220\]](#cite_note-MADO-2017-222)^ The 2018 [Madrid Pride](/wiki/Madrid_Pride "Madrid Pride") roughly had 1.5 million participants.^[\[137\]](#cite_note-MADdestino-138)^^p. 34^{#cite_ref-MADdestino_138-5}

Since Spain legalised [same-sex marriage](/wiki/Same-sex_marriage "Same-sex marriage") in July 2005,^[\[223\]](#cite_note-225)^ Madrid has become one of the largest hot spots for LGBT culture. With about 500 businesses aimed toward the LGBT community, Madrid has become a "Gateway of Diversity".^[\[221\]](#cite_note-MADO-2016-223)^{#cite_ref-MADO-2016_223-1}  

#### Other {#Other}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit&section=44 "Edit section: Other")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Madrid_-_Preg%C3%B3n_carnaval_-_130209_175842.jpg/220px-Madrid_-_Preg%C3%B3n_carnaval_-_130209_175842.jpg)](/wiki/File:Madrid_-_Preg%C3%B3n_carnaval_-_130209_175842.jpg) People in costumes during the proclamation (*pregón*) of the 2013 Carnival

Despite often being labelled as "having no tradition" by foreigners,^[\[224\]](#cite_note-alpuente-226)^ the [Carnival](/wiki/Carnival "Carnival") was popular in Madrid already in the 16th century. However, during the Francoist dictatorship the carnival was under government ban and the feasts suffered a big blow.^[\[224\]](#cite_note-alpuente-226)^^[\[225\]](#cite_note-227)^ It has been slowly recovering since then.{#cite_ref-227}

Other signalled days include the regional day (2 May) commemorating the [Dos de Mayo Uprising](/wiki/Dos_de_Mayo_Uprising "Dos de Mayo Uprising") (a public holiday), the feasts of San Antonio de la Florida (13 June), the feast of the Virgen de la Paloma (circa 15 August) or the day of the co-patron of Madrid, the [Virgin of Almudena](/wiki/Virgin_of_Almudena "Virgin of Almudena") (9 November), although the latter's celebrations are rather religious in nature.^[\[226\]](#cite_note-228)^{#cite_ref-228}

The most important musical event in the city is the [Mad Cool](/wiki/Mad_Cool "Mad Cool") festival; created in 2016, it reached an attendance of 240,000 during the three-day long schedule of the 2018 edition.^[\[137\]](#cite_note-MADdestino-138)^^p. 33^{#cite_ref-MADdestino_138-6}  

### Bullfighting {#Bullfighting}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit&section=45 "Edit section: Bullfighting")\]

Madrid hosts the largest *plaza de toros* (bullring) in Spain, [Las Ventas](/wiki/Las_Ventas "Las Ventas"), established in 1929. Las Ventas is considered by many to be the world centre of bullfighting and has a [seating capacity](/wiki/Seating_capacity "Seating capacity") of almost 25,000. Madrid's [bullfighting](/wiki/Bullfighting "Bullfighting") season begins in March and ends in October. Bullfights are held every day during the festivities of [San Isidro](/wiki/Isidore_the_Laborer "Isidore the Laborer") (Madrid's [patron saint](/wiki/Patron_saint "Patron saint")) from mid May to early June, and every Sunday, and [public holiday](/wiki/Holiday "Holiday"), the rest of the season. The style of the plaza is [Neo-Mudéjar](/wiki/Neo-Mud%C3%A9jar "Neo-Mudéjar"). Las Ventas also hosts music concerts and other events outside of the bullfighting season. There is great controversy in Madrid with bullfighting.^\[*[failed verification](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")*\]^^[\[227\]](#cite_note-229)^{#cite_ref-229}  

### Sport {#Sport}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit&section=46 "Edit section: Sport")\]  
Main article: [Sport in Madrid](/wiki/Sport_in_Madrid "Sport in Madrid")  

#### Football {#Football}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit&section=47 "Edit section: Football")\]  
Main article: [Football in Madrid](/wiki/Football_in_Madrid "Football in Madrid")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Torres_running_at_goal_-_CdR_-_RM_v_ATL.jpg/220px-Torres_running_at_goal_-_CdR_-_RM_v_ATL.jpg)](/wiki/File:Torres_running_at_goal_-_CdR_-_RM_v_ATL.jpg) The [Madrid Derby](/wiki/Madrid_Derby "Madrid Derby") at the [Santiago Bernabéu Stadium](/wiki/Santiago_Bernab%C3%A9u_Stadium "Santiago Bernabéu Stadium"), January 2015

[Real Madrid](/wiki/Real_Madrid_CF "Real Madrid CF"), founded in 1902, compete in [La Liga](/wiki/La_Liga "La Liga") and play their home games at the [Santiago Bernabéu Stadium](/wiki/Santiago_Bernab%C3%A9u_Stadium "Santiago Bernabéu Stadium"). The club is one of the most widely supported teams in the world and their supporters are referred to as *Madridistas* or *Merengues* (Meringues). Real's supporters in Madrid are often believed to be constituted principally of members of the middle classes, however, this claim is in dispute and has not been proved. It has also been suggested that a large proportion of Real Madrid's fans are members of the working class.^[\[228\]](#cite_note-230)^ The club was selected as the [best club of the 20th century](/wiki/FIFA_Club_of_the_Century "FIFA Club of the Century"), being the fifth [most valuable sports club](/wiki/Forbes_list_of_the_most_valuable_sports_teams "Forbes list of the most valuable sports teams") in the world and the [most successful Spanish football club](/wiki/List_of_football_clubs_in_Spain_by_major_honours_won "List of football clubs in Spain by major honours won") with a total of 104 official titles (this includes a record 15 [European Cups](/wiki/UEFA_Champions_League "UEFA Champions League") and a record 36 La Liga trophies).{#cite_ref-230}

[Atlético Madrid](/wiki/Atl%C3%A9tico_Madrid "Atlético Madrid"), founded in 1903, also compete in La Liga and play their home games at the [Metropolitano Stadium](/wiki/Metropolitano_Stadium "Metropolitano Stadium"). The club is well-supported in the city, having the third national fan base in Spain and their supporters are referred to as *Atléticos* or *Colchoneros* (The Mattressers). Atlético is believed to draw its support mostly from working class citizens.^[\[229\]](#cite_note-231)^ The club is considered an [elite European team](/wiki/UEFA_coefficient#Men's_club_coefficient "UEFA coefficient"), having won three [UEFA Europa League](/wiki/UEFA_Europa_League "UEFA Europa League") titles and reached three [European Cup finals](/wiki/List_of_European_Cup_and_UEFA_Champions_League_finals "List of European Cup and UEFA Champions League finals"). Domestically, Atletico have won eleven league titles and ten [Copa del Reys](/wiki/Copa_del_Rey "Copa del Rey").{#cite_ref-231}

[Rayo Vallecano](/wiki/Rayo_Vallecano "Rayo Vallecano"), founded in 1924, are the third most important football team of the city, based in the [Vallecas](/wiki/Vallecas "Vallecas") neighborhood. They currently compete in La Liga, having secured promotion in 2021. The club's fans tend to be very left-wing and are known as *[Buccaneers](/wiki/Buccaneer "Buccaneer")*.

[Getafe CF](/wiki/Getafe_CF "Getafe CF"), founded in 1983, also compete in La Liga and play their home games at the [Estadio Coliseum](/wiki/Estadio_Coliseum "Estadio Coliseum"). The club was promoted to La Liga for the first time in 2004, and participated in the top level of Spanish football for twelve years between 2004 and 2016, and again since 2017.

[CD Leganés](/wiki/CD_Legan%C3%A9s "CD Leganés"), founded in 1928, compete in [Segunda Division](/wiki/Segunda_Division "Segunda Division") and play their home games at the [Estadio Municipal de Butarque](/wiki/Estadio_Municipal_de_Butarque "Estadio Municipal de Butarque"). In the 2015--16 season, for the first time in their history, Leganés earned promotion to La Liga. They remained in the top flight for four seasons, reaching a peak of 13th in 2018--19, before relegation in the last game of the following season, a 2--2 home draw with Real Madrid.

Madrid has hosted five European Cup/Champions League finals: four at the Santiago Bernabéu, and the [2019 final](/wiki/2019_UEFA_Champions_League_Final "2019 UEFA Champions League Final") at the Metropolitano. The Bernabéu also hosted the [Euro 1964 Final](/wiki/1964_European_Nations%27_Cup_Final "1964 European Nations' Cup Final") (which [Spain](/wiki/Spain_national_football_team "Spain national football team") won) and the [1982 FIFA World Cup Final](/wiki/1982_FIFA_World_Cup_Final "1982 FIFA World Cup Final").  

#### Basketball {#Basketball}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit&section=48 "Edit section: Basketball")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Final_del_Campeonato_del_Mundo_de_Baloncesto_2014_en_Madrid.jpg/220px-Final_del_Campeonato_del_Mundo_de_Baloncesto_2014_en_Madrid.jpg)](/wiki/File:Final_del_Campeonato_del_Mundo_de_Baloncesto_2014_en_Madrid.jpg) The [2014 FIBA Basketball World Cup Final](/wiki/2014_FIBA_Basketball_World_Cup_Final "2014 FIBA Basketball World Cup Final") at the [Palacio de Deportes](/wiki/Palacio_de_Deportes_de_la_Comunidad_de_Madrid "Palacio de Deportes de la Comunidad de Madrid")

[Real Madrid Baloncesto](/wiki/Real_Madrid_Baloncesto "Real Madrid Baloncesto"), founded in 1931, compete in [Liga ACB](/wiki/Liga_ACB "Liga ACB") and play their home games at the [Palacio de Deportes](/wiki/Palacio_de_Deportes_de_la_Comunidad_de_Madrid "Palacio de Deportes de la Comunidad de Madrid") (WiZink Center). Real Madrid's basketball section, similar to its football team, is the most successful team in Europe, with a record 11 [EuroLeague](/wiki/EuroLeague "EuroLeague") titles. Domestically, they have clinched a record 36 league titles and a record 28 [Copa del Reys](/wiki/Copa_del_Rey_de_Baloncesto "Copa del Rey de Baloncesto").

[Club Baloncesto Estudiantes](/wiki/CB_Estudiantes "CB Estudiantes"), founded in 1948, compete in [LEB Oro](/wiki/Liga_Espa%C3%B1ola_de_Baloncesto "Liga Española de Baloncesto") and also play their home games at the Palacio de Deportes (WiZink Center). Until 2021, Estudiantes was one of only three teams that have never been relegated from [Spain's top division](/wiki/Spanish_basketball_league_system "Spanish basketball league system"). Historically, its achievements include three cup titles and four league runners-up placements.

Madrid has hosted six [European Cup/EuroLeague finals](/wiki/EuroLeague_Finals "EuroLeague Finals"), the last two at the Palacio de Deportes. The city also hosted the final matches for the [1986](/wiki/1986_FIBA_World_Championship "1986 FIBA World Championship") and [2014](/wiki/2014_FIBA_Basketball_World_Cup "2014 FIBA Basketball World Cup") [FIBA World Cups](/wiki/FIBA_Basketball_World_Cup "FIBA Basketball World Cup"), and the [EuroBasket 2007](/wiki/EuroBasket_2007 "EuroBasket 2007") final (all held at the Palacio de Deportes).  

#### Events {#Events}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit&section=49 "Edit section: Events")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Safina_and_Wozniacki_at_Women%27s_Final_%2810%29_%283622888926%29.jpg/220px-Safina_and_Wozniacki_at_Women%27s_Final_%2810%29_%283622888926%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Safina_and_Wozniacki_at_Women%27s_Final_(10)_(3622888926).jpg) The [2009 Madrid Open](/wiki/2009_Mutua_Madrile%C3%B1a_Madrid_Open_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles "2009 Mutua Madrileña Madrid Open – Women's Singles") Women's Final at the [Caja Mágica](/wiki/Caja_M%C3%A1gica "Caja Mágica")

The main annual international event in [cycling](/wiki/Cycle_sport "Cycle sport"), the [Vuelta a España](/wiki/Vuelta_a_Espa%C3%B1a "Vuelta a España") (La Vuelta), is one of the three worldwide prestigious three-week-long [Grand Tours](/wiki/Grand_Tours "Grand Tours"), and its final stages takes place in Madrid on the first Sunday of September. In [tennis](/wiki/Tennis "Tennis"), the city hosts [Madrid Open](/wiki/Madrid_Open_(tennis) "Madrid Open (tennis)"), both male and female versions, played on clay court. The event is part of the nine [ATP Masters 1000](/wiki/ATP_Tour_Masters_1000 "ATP Tour Masters 1000") and nine [WTA 1000 tournaments](/wiki/WTA_1000_tournaments "WTA 1000 tournaments"). It is held during the first week of May in the [Caja Mágica](/wiki/Caja_M%C3%A1gica "Caja Mágica"). Additionally, Madrid hosts the finals of the major tournament for men's national teams, [Davis Cup](/wiki/Davis_Cup "Davis Cup"), since [2019](/wiki/2019_Davis_Cup "2019 Davis Cup").  

#### Formula 1 {#Formula_1}
