[Formula 1](/wiki/Formula_One "Formula One") announced that Madrid will be hosting the 2026 [Spanish Grand Prix](/wiki/Spanish_Grand_Prix "Spanish Grand Prix") around the [IFEMA](/wiki/IFEMA_Palacio_Municipal "IFEMA Palacio Municipal") complex which includes the F1 Exhibition Centre and is close to the [Estadio Alfredo Di Stéfano](/wiki/Estadio_Alfredo_Di_St%C3%A9fano "Estadio Alfredo Di Stéfano") as well as the [Ciudad Real Madrid](/wiki/Ciudad_Real_Madrid "Ciudad Real Madrid").^[\[230\]](#cite_note-232)^^[\[231\]](#cite_note-233)^{#cite_ref-233}  

Education {#Education}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit&section=51 "Edit section: Education")\]  
Main article: [Education in Spain](/wiki/Education_in_Spain "Education in Spain")

[Education in Spain](/wiki/Education_in_Spain "Education in Spain") is free, and compulsory from 6 to 16 years. The [education system](/wiki/Education "Education") is called LOE (*Ley Orgánica de Educación* ).^[\[232\]](#cite_note-234)^{#cite_ref-234}  

### Universities {#Universities}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit&section=52 "Edit section: Universities")\]

Madrid is home to many public and [private universities](/wiki/Private_university "Private university"). Some of them are among the oldest in the world, and many of them are the most prestigious universities in Spain.

The [National Distance Education University](/wiki/Universidad_Nacional_de_Educaci%C3%B3n_a_Distancia "Universidad Nacional de Educación a Distancia") (*Universidad Nacional de Educación a Distancia* ; UNED) has as its mission the public service of higher education through the modality of distance education. At more than 205,000 students (2015), UNED has the largest student population in Spain and is one of the largest universities in Europe. Since 1972, UNED has sought to translate into action the principle of equal opportunity in access to higher education through a methodology based on the principles of distance learning and focused on the needs of the student.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Rectorado_de_la_Universidad_Complutense_de_Madrid.jpg/170px-Rectorado_de_la_Universidad_Complutense_de_Madrid.jpg)](/wiki/File:Rectorado_de_la_Universidad_Complutense_de_Madrid.jpg) The rectorate of the [Complutense University of Madrid](/wiki/Complutense_University_of_Madrid "Complutense University of Madrid")

The [Complutense University of Madrid](/wiki/Complutense_University_of_Madrid "Complutense University of Madrid") (*Universidad Complutense de Madrid* ; UCM) is the second largest university in Spain after UNED and one of the oldest universities in the world. It has over 11,000 staff members and a student population of 117,000. Most of the academic staff is Spanish. It is located on two campuses, the main one of [Ciudad Universitaria](/wiki/Ciudad_Universitaria_de_Madrid "Ciudad Universitaria de Madrid") in the [Moncloa-Aravaca](/wiki/Moncloa-Aravaca "Moncloa-Aravaca") district, and the secondary campus of Somosaguas, located outside the city limits in [Pozuelo de Alarcón](/wiki/Pozuelo_de_Alarc%C3%B3n "Pozuelo de Alarcón") and founded in 1971.^[\[233\]](#cite_note-235)^^[\[234\]](#cite_note-Universidad_Complutense-236)^ The Complutense University of Madrid was founded in [Alcalá de Henares](/wiki/Alcal%C3%A1_de_Henares "Alcalá de Henares"), old Complutum, by Cardinal Cisneros in 1499. Nevertheless, its real origin dates back to 1293, when King [Sancho IV of Castile](/wiki/Sancho_IV_of_Castile "Sancho IV of Castile") built the General Schools of Alcalá, which would give rise to Cisnero's Complutense University. Between 1509 and 1510, five schools were already operative: *Artes y Filosofía* (Arts and Philosophy), *Teología* (Theology), *Derecho Canónico* (Canonical Laws), *Letras* (Liberal Arts) and *Medicina* (Medicine). In 1836, during the reign of [Isabel II](/wiki/Isabella_II_of_Spain "Isabella II of Spain"), the university was moved to Madrid, where it took the name of Central University and was located at San Bernardo Street. Subsequently, in 1927, a new [University City](/wiki/University_City_of_Madrid "University City of Madrid") (Ciudad Universitaria) was planned to be built in the district of Moncloa-Aravaca, in lands handed over by the King [Alfonso XIII](/wiki/Alfonso_XIII_of_Spain "Alfonso XIII of Spain") to this purpose. The [Spanish Civil War](/wiki/Spanish_Civil_War "Spanish Civil War") turned the University City into a war zone, causing the destruction of several schools in the area, as well as the loss of part of its rich scientific, artistic and bibliographic heritage. In 1970 the Government reformed higher education, and the Central University became the Complutense University of Madrid. It was then that the new campus at Somosaguas was created to house the new School of Social Sciences. The old Alcalá campus was reopened as the independent UAH, [University of Alcalá](/wiki/University_of_Alcal%C3%A1 "University of Alcalá"), in 1977. Complutense also serves a population of students who select Madrid for their [study abroad](/wiki/Study_abroad "Study abroad") period. Students from the United States, for example, might go to Madrid on a program like API (Academic Programs International) and study at Complutense for an intense immersion in the Spanish language. After studying at the university, students return home with fluency in Spanish as well as an enhanced understanding of culture and diversity.^[\[235\]](#cite_note-Universidad_Complutense_de_Madrid-237)^{#cite_ref-Universidad_Complutense_de_Madrid_237-0}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Etsiminasmadrid.JPG/220px-Etsiminasmadrid.JPG)](/wiki/File:Etsiminasmadrid.JPG) School of Mines, [Technical University of Madrid](/wiki/Technical_University_of_Madrid "Technical University of Madrid")

The [Technical University of Madrid](/wiki/Technical_University_of_Madrid "Technical University of Madrid") (*Universidad Politécnica de Madrid* ; UPM), is the top technical university in Spain. It is the result of the merger of different [Technical Schools](/wiki/Technical_school "Technical school") of Engineering. It shares the Ciudad Universitaria campus with the UCM, while it also owns several schools scattered in the city centre and additional campuses in the [Puente de Vallecas](/wiki/Puente_de_Vallecas "Puente de Vallecas") district and in the neighbouring municipality of [Boadilla del Monte](/wiki/Boadilla_del_Monte "Boadilla del Monte").

The [Autonomous University of Madrid](/wiki/Autonomous_University_of_Madrid "Autonomous University of Madrid") (*Universidad Autónoma de Madrid* ; UAM) was instituted under the leadership of the physicist, [Nicolás Cabrera](/wiki/Nicol%C3%A1s_Cabrera_(physicist) "Nicolás Cabrera (physicist)"). The Autonomous University is widely recognised for its research strengths in [theoretical physics](/wiki/Theoretical_physics "Theoretical physics"). Known simply as *La Autónoma* by locals, its main site is the Cantoblanco Campus, located in the north of the municipality, close to its boundaries with the neighbouring municipalities of [Alcobendas](/wiki/Alcobendas "Alcobendas"), [San Sebastián de los Reyes](/wiki/San_Sebasti%C3%A1n_de_los_Reyes "San Sebastián de los Reyes") and [Tres Cantos](/wiki/Tres_Cantos "Tres Cantos").

Located on the main site are the Rectorate building and the Faculties of Science, Philosophy and [Fine Arts](/wiki/Fine_art "Fine art"), Law, [Economic Science](/wiki/Economics "Economics") and [Business Studies](/wiki/Business "Business"), Psychology, Higher School of [Computing Science](/wiki/Computer_science "Computer science") and Engineering, and the Faculty of [Teacher Training](/wiki/Teacher_education "Teacher education") and Education. The UAM is considered the institution to study law in Spain,^\[*[according to whom?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Unsupported_attributions "Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch")*\]^^[\[236\]](#cite_note-Elmundo.es-238)^ The [Medical School](/wiki/Medical_school "Medical school") is sited outside the main site and beside the Hospital Universitario La Paz.^[\[237\]](#cite_note-Universidad_Autónoma-239)^{#cite_ref-Universidad_Autónoma_239-0}

The private [Comillas Pontifical University](/wiki/Comillas_Pontifical_University "Comillas Pontifical University") (*Universidad Pontificia Comillas* , UPC) has its rectorate and several faculties in Madrid. The private [Nebrija University](/wiki/Nebrija_University "Nebrija University") is also based in Madrid. Some of the large public universities headquartered in the surrounding municipalities also have secondary campuses in Madrid proper: it is the case of the [Charles III University of Madrid](/wiki/Charles_III_University_of_Madrid "Charles III University of Madrid") (*Universidad Carlos III de Madrid* , UC3M) with its main site in [Getafe](/wiki/Getafe "Getafe") and an educational facility in [Embajadores](/wiki/Embajadores "Embajadores") (after signing a deal with the regional government and the city council in 2011)^[\[238\]](#cite_note-240)^ and the [King Juan Carlos University](/wiki/King_Juan_Carlos_University "King Juan Carlos University") (*Universidad Rey Juan Carlos* , URJC) having its main site in [Móstoles](/wiki/M%C3%B3stoles "Móstoles") and a secondary campus in [Vicálvaro](/wiki/Vic%C3%A1lvaro "Vicálvaro"). The private [Camilo José Cela University](/wiki/Universidad_Camilo_Jos%C3%A9_Cela "Universidad Camilo José Cela") (*Universidad Camilo José Cela* , UCJC) has a postgraduate school in [Chamberí](/wiki/Chamber%C3%AD "Chamberí").{#cite_ref-240}  

### Business schools {#Business_schools}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit&section=53 "Edit section: Business schools")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/IE_Business_School17.JPG/220px-IE_Business_School17.JPG)](/wiki/File:IE_Business_School17.JPG) Students of the IE Business School

[IE Business School](/wiki/IE_Business_School "IE Business School") (formerly Instituto de Empresa) has its main campus on the border of the Chamartín and Salamanca districts of Madrid. IE Business School recently ranked #1 in WSJ's 2009 rankings for Best MBA Programs under 2 years. It scored ahead of usual stalwarts, [INSEAD](/wiki/INSEAD "INSEAD") and [IMD](/wiki/International_Institute_for_Management_Development "International Institute for Management Development"), giving it top billing among International MBA programs. Although based in [Barcelona](/wiki/Barcelona "Barcelona"), both [IESE Business School](/wiki/IESE "IESE") and [ESADE Business School](/wiki/ESADE_Business_School "ESADE Business School") also have Madrid campuses. These three schools are the top-ranked [business schools](/wiki/Business_school "Business school") in Spain, consistently rank among the top 20 business schools globally, and offer [MBA](/wiki/Master_of_Business_Administration "Master of Business Administration") programs (in English or Spanish) as well as other business degrees. Madrid is a good destination for business schools and a city much desired by foreign students. The most important Spanish business schools (IESE, IE, ESADE) have invested 125 million euros in expanding their campuses in Madrid in 2020.^[\[239\]](#cite_note-241)^{#cite_ref-241}

Other Madrid business schools and universities that have MBA programs include: [EAE Business School](/wiki/EAE_Business_School "EAE Business School") (in English and Spanish), the [Charles III University of Madrid](/wiki/Charles_III_University_of_Madrid "Charles III University of Madrid") through the *Centro de Ampliación de Estudios* (in English or Spanish); the [Comillas Pontifical University](/wiki/Comillas_Pontifical_University "Comillas Pontifical University") (in Spanish only) and the [Technical University of Madrid](/wiki/Technical_University_of_Madrid "Technical University of Madrid") (in Spanish only).  

Transport {#Transport}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit&section=54 "Edit section: Transport")\]  
Main article: [Transport in Madrid](/wiki/Transport_in_Madrid "Transport in Madrid")

In 2018, Madrid banned all non-resident vehicles from its downtown areas.^[\[240\]](#cite_note-Jones-2018-242)^^[\[241\]](#cite_note-243)^{#cite_ref-243}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/M-30_%28Madrid%2C_Spain%29_04.jpg/220px-M-30_%28Madrid%2C_Spain%29_04.jpg)](/wiki/File:M-30_(Madrid,_Spain)_04.jpg) The M-607 meets the M-30 north of the municipality.

Madrid is served by several roads and three modes of public surface transport, and two airports, one of them being almost two different airports. A great many important road, rail and air links converge on the capital, providing effective connections with other parts of the metropolitan region and with the rest of Spain and other parts of Europe.

In the 1960s, sweeping urban reforms were promoted to accommodate Madrid to the private car (most notably the removal of boulevards and the incorporation of overpasses), in some ways similarly to other European cities, but in the distinct context of poverty of public debate, which was limited by a dictatorship putting its own interests and those of its clientelist networks before other concerns when it came to alter the urban fabric, thereby marginizalizing the pedestrian.^[\[242\]](#cite_note-244)^{#cite_ref-244}  

### Road transport {#Road_transport}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit&section=55 "Edit section: Road transport")\]


Madrid Central  
Main article: [Madrid Central](/wiki/Madrid_Central "Madrid Central")

Cars (except for hybrid and electric vehicles as well as residents and guests) were banned in the [Madrid Central](/wiki/Madrid_Central "Madrid Central") low-emission zone in 2018.^[\[243\]](#cite_note-citylabcarban-245)^^[\[244\]](#cite_note-246)^ Pollution in the area dropped following the ban.^[\[245\]](#cite_note-247)^^[\[243\]](#cite_note-citylabcarban-245)^ In 2016 it was announced that Madrid will stop the use of all diesel powered cars and trucks within the next decade.^[\[246\]](#cite_note-248)^{#cite_ref-248}


Radial roads
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/Red_alta_capacidad_espa%C3%B1a.svg/220px-Red_alta_capacidad_espa%C3%B1a.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Red_alta_capacidad_espa%C3%B1a.svg) The network of high capacity roads in Spain features its most important node in Madrid.

Madrid is the centre of the most important roads of Spain. Already in 1720, the *Reglamento General de Postas* enacted by [Philip V](/wiki/Philip_V_of_Spain "Philip V of Spain") configurated the basis of a radial system of roads in the country.^[\[247\]](#cite_note-249)^{#cite_ref-249}

Madrid features a number of the most prominent *[autovías](/wiki/Autov%C3%ADa "Autovía")* (fast dualled highways), part of the [State Road Network](/w/index.php?title=State_Road_Network&action=edit&redlink=1 "State Road Network (page does not exist)") \[[es](https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Red_de_Carreteras_del_Estado "es:Red de Carreteras del Estado")\]. Clock-wise starting from the north: the [A-1](/wiki/Autov%C3%ADa_A-1 "Autovía A-1") (Madrid--[Irún](/wiki/Ir%C3%BAn "Irún")--[French border](/wiki/France "France")), [A-2](/wiki/Autov%C3%ADa_A-2 "Autovía A-2") (Madrid--[Zaragoza](/wiki/Zaragoza "Zaragoza")--[Barcelona](/wiki/Barcelona "Barcelona")--French border), [A-3](/wiki/Autov%C3%ADa_A-3 "Autovía A-3") (Madrid--[Valencia](/wiki/Valencia,_Spain "Valencia, Spain")), [A-4](/wiki/Autov%C3%ADa_A-4 "Autovía A-4") (Madrid--[Córdoba](/wiki/C%C3%B3rdoba,_Spain "Córdoba, Spain")--[Sevilla](/wiki/Sevilla "Sevilla")--[Cádiz](/wiki/C%C3%A1diz "Cádiz")), [A-5](/wiki/Autov%C3%ADa_A-5 "Autovía A-5") (Madrid--[Badajoz](/wiki/Badajoz "Badajoz")--[Portuguese border](/wiki/Portugal "Portugal")) and the [A-6](/wiki/Autov%C3%ADa_A-6 "Autovía A-6") (Madrid--[A Coruña](/wiki/A_Coru%C3%B1a "A Coruña")). The [A-42](/wiki/Autov%C3%ADa_A-42 "Autovía A-42"), another highway connecting Madrid to [Toledo](/wiki/Toledo,_Spain "Toledo, Spain"), is also part of the State Network.

The [M-607](/w/index.php?title=M-607&action=edit&redlink=1 "M-607 (page does not exist)") connects Madrid to the [Puerto de Navacerrada](/wiki/Puerto_de_Navacerrada "Puerto de Navacerrada"). It is a fast dualled highway in its initial stretch from Madrid to [Colmenar Viejo](/wiki/Colmenar_Viejo "Colmenar Viejo"), and part of the [Regional Road Network](/w/index.php?title=Regional_Road_Network&action=edit&redlink=1 "Regional Road Network (page does not exist)") \[[es](https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anexo:Red_de_Carreteras_de_la_Comunidad_de_Madrid "es:Anexo:Red de Carreteras de la Comunidad de Madrid")\] (in relation to the concerning administration, not to the technical features of the road).

Due to the large amount of traffic, new toll highways were built parallel to the main national freeways. Their names are [R-2](/w/index.php?title=R-2_motorway_(Spain)&action=edit&redlink=1 "R-2 motorway (Spain) (page does not exist)") \[[es](https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autopista_Radial_2 "es:Autopista Radial 2")\], [R-3](/wiki/R-3_motorway_(Spain) "R-3 motorway (Spain)"), [R-4](/wiki/R-4_motorway_(Spain) "R-4 motorway (Spain)") and [R-5](/w/index.php?title=R-5_motorway_(Spain)&action=edit&redlink=1 "R-5 motorway (Spain) (page does not exist)") \[[es](https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autopista_Radial_5 "es:Autopista Radial 5")\] and they were intended to provide a paid alternative to the often overcrowded free radials. However, except the R-3, they do not end close to the M-30 innermost ring road, as the R-2 finishes in the M-40, the R-4 in the M-50 and the R-5 in the M-40.


Orbital roads
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/M_30_tunel.jpg/220px-M_30_tunel.jpg)](/wiki/File:M_30_tunel.jpg) M-30 tunnel parallel to the Manzanares

Also Madrid road network includes four [orbital](/wiki/Ring_road "Ring road") ones at different distances from the centre. The innermost ring-road, the [M-30](/wiki/Autopista_de_Circunvalaci%C3%B3n_M-30 "Autopista de Circunvalación M-30"), is the only one with its path strictly located within the Madrid municipal limits. It is owned by the [Madrid City Council](/wiki/Madrid_City_Council "Madrid City Council") and operated by Madrid Calle 30, S.A. It is the busiest Spanish road, famous for its traffic jams. A significant portion of the southern part runs underground parallel to the [Manzanares](/wiki/Manzanares_River "Manzanares River"), with tunnel sections of more than 6 km (3.7 mi) in length and 3 to 6 lanes in each direction.

The second ring-road, the [M-40](/wiki/Autopista_de_Circunvalaci%C3%B3n_M-40 "Autopista de Circunvalación M-40") (part of the State Road Network) circles the city, while also extending to other surrounding municipalities. A NW stretch of the road runs underground, below the southern reaches of the [Monte de El Pardo](/wiki/Monte_de_El_Pardo "Monte de El Pardo") protected area.

The [M-45](/w/index.php?title=Autopista_de_Circunvalaci%C3%B3n_M-45&action=edit&redlink=1 "Autopista de Circunvalación M-45 (page does not exist)") partially circles the city, connecting the M-40 and M-50, passing through areas like Villaverde and Vallecas in the southeast of the municipality.

The [M-50](/wiki/Autopista_de_Circunvalaci%C3%B3n_M-50 "Autopista de Circunvalación M-50"), the Madrid's outer ring road, connects municipalities and cities in the metropolitan area, like [Fuenlabrada](/wiki/Fuenlabrada "Fuenlabrada"), [Móstoles](/wiki/M%C3%B3stoles "Móstoles"), [Getafe](/wiki/Getafe "Getafe"), [Leganés](/wiki/Legan%C3%A9s "Leganés") in the south and [Boadilla del Monte](/wiki/Boadilla_del_Monte "Boadilla del Monte") and [Las Rozas](/wiki/Las_Rozas_de_Madrid "Las Rozas de Madrid") in the west.  

### Public transport {#Public_transport}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit&section=56 "Edit section: Public transport")\]  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Madrid_Metro_Map.svg/220px-Madrid_Metro_Map.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Madrid_Metro_Map.svg)  
Map of the [Madrid Metro](/wiki/Madrid_Metro "Madrid Metro")  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/CercaniasMadrid2018.png/220px-CercaniasMadrid2018.png)](/wiki/File:CercaniasMadrid2018.png)  
[Cercanías Madrid](/wiki/Cercan%C3%ADas_Madrid "Cercanías Madrid") map

There are four major components of public transport, with many [intermodal interchanges](/wiki/Transport_hub "Transport hub"). The [Consorcio Regional de Transportes de Madrid](/wiki/Consorcio_Regional_de_Transportes_de_Madrid "Consorcio Regional de Transportes de Madrid") (CRTM) coordinates the [public transport](/wiki/Public_transport "Public transport") operations across multiple providers in the region,^[\[248\]](#cite_note-250)^^[\[249\]](#cite_note-251)^ harmonizing fares for the commuter rail, rapid transit, light rail and bus transport services provided by different operators.{#cite_ref-251}


Metro  
Main article: [Madrid Metro](/wiki/Madrid_Metro "Madrid Metro")

The Metro is the [rapid transit](/wiki/Rapid_transit "Rapid transit") system serving Madrid as well as some suburbs. Founded in 1919, it underwent extensive enlargement in the second half of the 20th century.^[\[250\]](#cite_note-transport-252)^ It is the third longest metro system in Europe (after [Moscow](/wiki/Moscow_Metro "Moscow Metro") and [London](/wiki/London_Subway "London Subway")) at 294 km (183 mi). As of 2019^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit)^, it has 302 stations.^[\[251\]](#cite_note-253)^ Only the Métro of Paris has more stations. It features 13 lines; 12 of them are colour-coded and numbered 1 to 12 ([Line 1](/wiki/Line_1_(Madrid_Metro) "Line 1 (Madrid Metro)"), [Line 2](/wiki/Line_2_(Madrid_Metro) "Line 2 (Madrid Metro)"), [Line 3](/wiki/Line_3_(Madrid_Metro) "Line 3 (Madrid Metro)"), [Line 4](/wiki/Line_4_(Madrid_Metro) "Line 4 (Madrid Metro)"), [Line 5](/wiki/Line_5_(Madrid_Metro) "Line 5 (Madrid Metro)"), [Line 6](/wiki/Line_6_(Madrid_Metro) "Line 6 (Madrid Metro)"), [Line 7](/wiki/Line_7_(Madrid_Metro) "Line 7 (Madrid Metro)"), [Line 8](/wiki/Line_8_(Madrid_Metro) "Line 8 (Madrid Metro)"), [Line 9](/wiki/Line_9_(Madrid_Metro) "Line 9 (Madrid Metro)"), [Line 10](/wiki/Line_10_(Madrid_Metro) "Line 10 (Madrid Metro)"), [Line 11](/wiki/Line_11_(Madrid_Metro) "Line 11 (Madrid Metro)") and [Line 12](/wiki/Line_12_(Madrid_Metro) "Line 12 (Madrid Metro)")), while the other one, the short *[Ramal](/wiki/Ramal_(Madrid_Metro) "Ramal (Madrid Metro)")* (R), links Ópera to Príncipe Pío.^[\[250\]](#cite_note-transport-252)^{#cite_ref-transport_252-1}


Cercanías  
Main article: [Cercanías Madrid](/wiki/Cercan%C3%ADas_Madrid "Cercanías Madrid")

Cercanías Madrid is the [commuter rail](/wiki/Commuter_rail "Commuter rail") service used for longer distances from the suburbs and beyond into Madrid, consisting of nine lines totalling 578 km (359 mi) and more than 90 stations. With fewer stops inside the centre of the city they are faster than the Metro, but run less frequently. This system is connected with Metro (presently 22 stations) and Light Metro. The lines are named: [C-1](/wiki/C-1_(Cercan%C3%ADas_Madrid) "C-1 (Cercanías Madrid)"), [C-2](/wiki/C-2_(Cercan%C3%ADas_Madrid) "C-2 (Cercanías Madrid)"), [C-3](/wiki/C-3_(Cercan%C3%ADas_Madrid) "C-3 (Cercanías Madrid)"), [C-4](/wiki/C-4_(Cercan%C3%ADas_Madrid) "C-4 (Cercanías Madrid)"), [C-5](/wiki/C-5_(Cercan%C3%ADas_Madrid) "C-5 (Cercanías Madrid)"), [C-7](/wiki/C-7_(Cercan%C3%ADas_Madrid) "C-7 (Cercanías Madrid)"), [C-8](/wiki/C-8_(Cercan%C3%ADas_Madrid) "C-8 (Cercanías Madrid)"), [C-9](/wiki/C-9_(Cercan%C3%ADas_Madrid) "C-9 (Cercanías Madrid)"), [C-10](/wiki/C-10_(Cercan%C3%ADas_Madrid) "C-10 (Cercanías Madrid)"), respectively.


Buses

There is a dense network of [bus](/wiki/Bus "Bus") routes, run by the municipal company [Empresa Municipal de Transportes](/wiki/Empresa_Municipal_de_Transportes_de_Madrid "Empresa Municipal de Transportes de Madrid") (or EMT Madrid), which operates 24 hours a day; special services called "N lines" are run during nighttime. The special Airport Express Shuttle line connecting the airport with the city centre features distinctively yellow buses. In addition to the urban lines operated by the EMT, the green buses (*interurbanos*) connect the city with the suburbs. The later lines, while also regulated by the CRTM, are often run by private operators.

Almost half of all journeys in the metropolitan area are made on public transport, a very high proportion compared with most European cities.^[\[129\]](#cite_note-Estructura-130)^^: 62--4^ Madrid has 15723 taxis around all the city.{#cite_ref-Estructura_130-33}


Taxi

The taxicabs are regulated by a specific sub-division of taxi service, a body dependent of the [Madrid City Council](/wiki/Madrid_City_Council "Madrid City Council"). The authorisation entails a badge for the vehicle and a license for the driver, who has to be older than 18.^[\[252\]](#cite_note-254)^ Since the 1970s, the fleet of taxis has remained stable roughly around 16,000 vehicles, accounting for 15,600 in 2014.^[\[253\]](#cite_note-255)^{#cite_ref-255}  

### Long-distance transport {#Long-distance_transport}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit&section=57 "Edit section: Long-distance transport")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Estaci%C3%B3n_de_Madrid_Puerta_de_Atocha%2C_tren_AVE_con_destino_Valencia%2C_Espa%C3%B1a._Renfe_serie_112.JPG/220px-Estaci%C3%B3n_de_Madrid_Puerta_de_Atocha%2C_tren_AVE_con_destino_Valencia%2C_Espa%C3%B1a._Renfe_serie_112.JPG)](/wiki/File:Estaci%C3%B3n_de_Madrid_Puerta_de_Atocha,_tren_AVE_con_destino_Valencia,_Espa%C3%B1a._Renfe_serie_112.JPG) [AVE](/wiki/AVE "AVE") rolling stock at the [Madrid Atocha](/wiki/Madrid_Atocha "Madrid Atocha") station

In terms of longer-distance transport, Madrid is the central node of the system of *[autovías](/wiki/Autov%C3%ADa "Autovía")* , giving the city direct fast road links with most parts of Spain and with France and Portugal. It is also the focal point of [Spain's high-speed rail system](/wiki/High-speed_rail_in_Spain "High-speed rail in Spain"). The most demanded train routes link Madrid to [Barcelona](/wiki/Barcelona "Barcelona"), [Valencia](/wiki/Valencia "Valencia"), [Seville](/wiki/Seville "Seville"), and [Málaga](/wiki/M%C3%A1laga "Málaga").^[\[254\]](#cite_note-256)^ There are now 2,900 km (1,800 mi) of high-speed rail track, connecting Madrid with 17 provincial capitals, and further lines are under construction.^[\[129\]](#cite_note-Estructura-130)^^: 72--75^{#cite_ref-Estructura_130-34}

Spanish companies are designing new high-speed trains which will be the new-generation [AVE](/wiki/AVE "AVE"), much like the current [Talgo AVRIL](/wiki/Talgo_AVRIL "Talgo AVRIL").

Aside from the local and regional bus commuting services, Madrid is also a node for long-distance bus connections to many national destinations. The [Estación Sur de Autobuses](/w/index.php?title=Estaci%C3%B3n_Sur_de_Autobuses&action=edit&redlink=1 "Estación Sur de Autobuses (page does not exist)") \[[es](https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Estaci%C3%B3n_Sur_de_Autobuses "es:Estación Sur de Autobuses")\] in Méndez Álvaro, the busiest bus station in the country,^[\[255\]](#cite_note-ep-257)^ also features international bus connections to cities in [Morocco](/wiki/Morocco "Morocco") as well as to diverse European destinations.^[\[255\]](#cite_note-ep-257)^{#cite_ref-ep_257-1}  

### Airport {#Airport}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit&section=58 "Edit section: Airport")\]  
Main article: [Madrid-Barajas Airport](/wiki/Madrid-Barajas_Airport "Madrid-Barajas Airport")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Terminal_4_del_aeropuerto_de_Madrid-Barajas%2C_Espa%C3%B1a%2C_2013-01-09%2C_DD_05.jpg/220px-Terminal_4_del_aeropuerto_de_Madrid-Barajas%2C_Espa%C3%B1a%2C_2013-01-09%2C_DD_05.jpg)](/wiki/File:Terminal_4_del_aeropuerto_de_Madrid-Barajas,_Espa%C3%B1a,_2013-01-09,_DD_05.jpg) Interior of the terminal 4 (T4) of the [Madrid--Barajas Airport](/wiki/Madrid%E2%80%93Barajas_Airport "Madrid–Barajas Airport")

Madrid is also home to the Madrid-Barajas Airport, the sixth-busiest airport in Europe, handling over 60 million passengers annually, of whom 70% are international travellers, in addition to the majority of Spain's [air freight](/wiki/Air_freight "Air freight") movements.^[\[129\]](#cite_note-Estructura-130)^^: 76--78^ Barajas is a major European hub, largely westward facing, specialized in the [Americas](/wiki/Americas "Americas"), with a comparatively lighter connectivity to Asia.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^ Madrid's location at the centre of the [Iberian Peninsula](/wiki/Iberian_Peninsula "Iberian Peninsula") makes it a major [logistics](/wiki/Logistics "Logistics") base.^[\[129\]](#cite_note-Estructura-130)^^: 79--80^ Madrid-Barajas Airport has 4 terminals plus terminal 4S, called the Satellite terminal; this terminal is 2 km (1.2 mi) from terminal 4 and connected by an Automated [People Mover](/wiki/People_Mover "People Mover") System (APM) train.{#cite_ref-Estructura_130-36}

The smaller (and older) [Cuatro Vientos Airport](/wiki/Cuatro_Vientos_Airport "Cuatro Vientos Airport") has a dual military-civilian use and hosts several aviation schools. The [Torrejón Air Base](/wiki/Torrej%C3%B3n_Air_Base "Torrejón Air Base"), located in the neighbouring municipality of [Torrejón de Ardoz](/wiki/Torrej%C3%B3n_de_Ardoz "Torrejón de Ardoz"), also has a secondary civilian use aside from the military purpose.

### Diplomacy {#Diplomacy}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit&section=60 "Edit section: Diplomacy")\]

Madrid hosts [121 foreign embassies](/wiki/List_of_diplomatic_missions_in_Spain "List of diplomatic missions in Spain") accredited before Spain,^[\[256\]](#cite_note-258)^ comprising the totality of resident embassies in the country. The headquarters of the Spanish [Ministry of Foreign Affairs, European Union and Cooperation](/wiki/Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs_(Spain) "Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Spain)"), the [Spanish Agency for International Development Cooperation](/wiki/Spanish_Agency_for_International_Development_Cooperation "Spanish Agency for International Development Cooperation") and the [Diplomatic School](/wiki/Diplomatic_School_of_Spain "Diplomatic School of Spain") are also located in the city.{#cite_ref-258}  

### International organizations {#International_organizations}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Madrid&action=edit&section=61 "Edit section: International organizations")\]

Madrid hosts the seat of international organizations such as the United Nations' [World Tourism Organization](/wiki/World_Tourism_Organization "World Tourism Organization") (UNWTO), the [Ibero-American General Secretariat](/wiki/Ibero-American_General_Secretariat "Ibero-American General Secretariat") (SEGIB), the [Organization of Ibero-American States](/wiki/Organization_of_Ibero-American_States "Organization of Ibero-American States") (OEI), the [International Youth Organism for Iberoamerica](/w/index.php?title=International_Youth_Organism_for_Iberoamerica&action=edit&redlink=1 "International Youth Organism for Iberoamerica (page does not exist)") \[[es](https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Organismo_Internacional_de_Juventud_para_Iberoam%C3%A9rica "es:Organismo Internacional de Juventud para Iberoamérica")\] (OIJ), the [Ibero-American Organization of Social Security](/w/index.php?title=Ibero-American_Organization_of_Social_Security&action=edit&redlink=1 "Ibero-American Organization of Social Security (page does not exist)") \[[es](https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Organizaci%C3%B3n_Iberoamericana_de_Seguridad_Social "es:Organización Iberoamericana de Seguridad Social")\] (OISS), the [International Organization of Securities Commissions](/wiki/International_Organization_of_Securities_Commissions "International Organization of Securities Commissions") (IOSCO), the [Club of Madrid](/wiki/Club_of_Madrid "Club of Madrid") and the [International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas](/wiki/International_Commission_for_the_Conservation_of_Atlantic_Tunas "International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas") (ICCAT).

183. **[\^](#cite_ref-Gili_185-0)** Citado en Quilis, *Los Pronombres "le", "la", "lo" y sus plurales en la lengua española hablada en Madrid* , pag. 36.   
     *Según Gili Gaya (1958, 210-211), el 'le' dativo, que, como se sabe, es invariable para los 2 géneros, se ha especializado como masculino: 'le regalaron una bicicleta' (a él); y cuando es femeninose sustituye por 'la', procedente del acusativo: la regalaron una bicicleta' (a ella). "Este es el uso madrileño espontáneo en todas las clases sociales, a no ser entre personas cuya instrucción gramatical, o la procedencia de otras regiones, lo corrija más o menos. La influencia de la capital irradia su laísmo hacia otras provincias del Centro y del Norte, llegando a vencer a menudo la resistencia del lenguaje literario. El vulgo madrileño va todavía más allá: el 'lo' sustituye con frecuencia a 'le' como dativo: 'lo pegaron una bofetada'. Sin embargo, este 'loísmo' se siente en todas partes como extremadamente plebeyo, y no ha logrado salir del habla achulapada."*{#cite_note-Gili-185}
{#cite_note-Gili-185}
